title: Columbia County Wa governance

communications.subject: Washington Public Records Act Request: Columbia County Wa governance
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Washington Public Records Act, I hereby request the following records:

Complete personnal files of all Sheriff’s Office deputies specifically disciplinary records, training, and certifications. 

All emails sent and received between chief deputy Conner Ehr and Sheriff Joe Helm from August 1st, 2019- present 

All emails sent and received between Ashley Strickland and Sheriff Joe Helm.

All emails sent and received between Ashley Strickland and Under Sheriff Robbie Patterson.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 5 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Lizbeth Salander

title: Request to CIA for all communications with Richard North Patterson between 2008 and 2012

communications.subject: Freedom of Information Act Request: Request to CIA for all communications with Richard North Patterson between 2008 and 2012
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Freedom of Information Act, I hereby request the following records:

All communications between the Central Intelligence Agency or employees thereof and author Richard North Patterson (born February 22, 1947, in Berkeley, California) between 2008 and 2012, or any of those years that fall within the record retention schedule(s) for such documents within the relevant office(s). Such communications may include, but should not be limited to, emails, correspondence, memos, and transcriptions of telephone calls.

I am the Director of Research Operations at a 501(c)(3) non-profit organization called The Decoding Culture Foundation. These documents will be used for public education and research purposes. I therefore request a waiver of all fees that may otherwise apply. Attached is a document with organization letterhead confirming my position, as well as the organization's 501(c)(3) application and approval form.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 20 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Brett Carollo

title: NASA support for 2014 Pink Floyd music video "Marooned"

communications.subject: Freedom of Information Act Request: NASA support for 2014 Pink Floyd music video "Marooned"
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Freedom of Information Act, I hereby request the following records:

All documents pertaining to NASA's support for the Pink Floyd music video "Marooned," released in 2014 and directed by Aubrey Powell. NASA's support for the video is apparently confirmed by the inclusion of an entry for "Pink Floyd" in a list 2014 NASA-supported entertainment released to me by FOIA. I request any and all documents pertaining to NASA support for the Pink Floyd music video "Marooned." Such documents may include but should not be not limited to: script notes; production assistance agreements; and all records of communications between employees of NASA and members of the cast, crew, and production company of "Marooned," including memos, notes of meetings and conference calls, emails, and other forms of communication.

I am the Director of Research Operations at a 501(c)(3) non-profit organization called The Decoding Culture Foundation as well as the editor-in-chief and a contributor to a research magazine published by said foundation titled "Cultural Engineering Studies." These documents will be used for public education and research purposes. I therefore request a waiver of all fees that may otherwise apply. Attached is a document with organization letterhead confirming my position, as well as the organization's 501(c)(3) application and approval form.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 20 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Brett Carollo

title: Request to DoD for all communications with documentary filmmaker Tony Gerber

communications.subject: Freedom of Information Act Request: Request to DoD for all communications with documentary filmmaker Tony Gerber
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Freedom of Information Act, I hereby request the following records:

All communications between the Department of Defense (DoD) and the documentary filmmaker Tony Gerber (born in New York, New York) between the years 2007 and 2009, around the time of the production and release of a documentary he co-directed titled "Full Battle Rattle" (2008). Such communications may include, but should not be limited to, emails, correspondence, memos, and transcriptions of telephone calls. These records fall within the records retention schedule of DoD as specified on p. 202 of the May 2022 DoD document titled "Records Disposition Schedules," Record Group 303.

I am the Director of Research Operations at a 501(c)(3) non-profit organization called The Decoding Culture Foundation as well as the editor-in-chief and a contributor to a research magazine published by said foundation titled "Cultural Engineering Studies." These documents will be used for public education and research purposes. I therefore request a waiver of all fees that may otherwise apply. Attached is a document with organization letterhead confirming my position, as well as the organization's 501(c)(3) application and approval form.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Sincerely,

Brett Carollo

title: Marines support for TV series "This American Land"

communications.subject: Freedom of Information Act Request: Marines support for TV series "This American Land"
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Freedom of Information Act, I hereby request the following records:

All documents pertaining to collaboration between the US Marine Corps and the production of one or more episodes of the TV series "This American Land" (2011-present), hosted by Bruce Burckhardt. According to a document released to me by the Marines through FOIA (see attached), the Marines provided support to this production in 2022. I therefore request any and all documents pertaining to Marine Corps support for "This American Land," inclusive of all episodes supported. Such documents may include but should not be not limited to: script notes; production assistance agreements; and all records of communications between employees of the Marines and members of the cast, crew, and production company of "This American Land," including memos, notes of meetings and conference calls, emails, and other forms of communication.

I am the Director of Research Operations at a 501(c)(3) non-profit organization called The Decoding Culture Foundation. These documents will be used for public education and research purposes. I therefore request a waiver of all fees that may otherwise apply. Attached is a document with organization letterhead confirming my position, as well as the organization's 501(c)(3) application and approval form.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 20 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Brett Carollo

title: Contract Awarded to Registry One for Connecticut Early Childhood Registry System

communications.subject: Connecticut Freedom of Information Act Request: Contract Awarded to Registry One for Connecticut Early Childhood Registry System
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Connecticut Freedom of Information Act, I hereby request the following records:

Contract and all related documents for a contract awarded to  Registry One for the CT early childhood registry system.

I also request that, if possible and pursuant to Conn. Gen. Stat. § 1-212(d), fees be waived as I believe this request is in the public interest and not made for commercial gain. The requested documents will be made available to the public at MuckRock.com.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 4 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Toni Thompson

communications.subject: FOI Records Request :: R000059-112724
communications.communication:
Dear Toni Thompson: 
 
 
This message is an acknowledgement that the Connecticut Office of Early Childhood received your Freedom of Information Act request on 11/27/2024. It was given the reference number R000059-112724 for tracking purposes. 
 
 
This letter does not constitute a denial of your request. Rather, in accordance with the Freedom of Information Act, we are in the process of researching and gathering documentation which may be responsive to it. Once the documents are gathered, we will then conduct a review to determine if statutory exemptions to disclosure may apply to some or all of the documents. Upon completion of that review, we will be able to provide you with any responsive, non-exempt documents. 
 
Please note the department reserves the right to charge any such other fees as may be appropriate pursuant to the Freedom of Information Act. 
You can monitor the progress of your request at the link below and you'll receive an email when your request has been completed. Again, thank you for using the OEC FOI Records Center. 
Connecticut Office of Early Childhood

communications.subject: FOI Records Request :: R000058-112724
communications.communication:
Dear Toni Thompson: 
 
 
This message is an acknowledgement that the Connecticut Office of Early Childhood received your Freedom of Information Act request on 11/27/2024. It was given the reference number R000058-112724 for tracking purposes. 
 
 
This letter does not constitute a denial of your request. Rather, in accordance with the Freedom of Information Act, we are in the process of researching and gathering documentation which may be responsive to it. Once the documents are gathered, we will then conduct a review to determine if statutory exemptions to disclosure may apply to some or all of the documents. Upon completion of that review, we will be able to provide you with any responsive, non-exempt documents. 
 
Please note the department reserves the right to charge any such other fees as may be appropriate pursuant to the Freedom of Information Act. 
You can monitor the progress of your request at the link below and you'll receive an email when your request has been completed. Again, thank you for using the OEC FOI Records Center. 
Connecticut Office of Early Childhood

title: Marines support for 2023 film Mission: Impossible - Dead Reckoning Part One

communications.subject: Freedom of Information Act Request: Marines support for 2023 film Mission: Impossible - Dead Reckoning Part One
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Freedom of Information Act, I hereby request the following records:

All documents pertaining to collaboration between the US Marine Corps and the production of the 2023 movie "Mission: Impossible -- Dead Reckoning Part One" (also known as "Mission: Impossible 7"), directed by Christopher McQuarrie and starring Tom Cruise. According to documents released to me by the Marines through FOIA (see attached), the Marines provided support to this production in 2022. I therefore request any and all documents pertaining to Marine Corps support for "Mission: Impossible -- Dead Reckoning Part One." Such documents may include but should not be not limited to: script notes; production assistance agreements; and all records of communications between employees of the Marines and members of the cast, crew, and production company of "Mission: Impossible -- Dead Reckoning Part One," including memos, notes of meetings and conference calls, emails, and other forms of communication.

I am the Director of Research Operations at a 501(c)(3) non-profit organization called The Decoding Culture Foundation. These documents will be used for public education and research purposes. I therefore request a waiver of all fees that may otherwise apply. Attached is a document with organization letterhead confirming my position, as well as the organization's 501(c)(3) application and approval form.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 20 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Brett Carollo

title: Earl Lawrence Durham

communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Freedom of Information Act, I hereby request the following records:

Records mentioning, relating, to, or generated as a result of investigation or inquiry of Earl Lawrence Durham (d. October 27, 2007), including files 100-HQ-248516 and 100-CG-12890. Previously released records indicate Durham was the subject of wiretapping and had at least one informant reporting on his activities. The following symbol sources were directed at Durham between 1954 and 1956: CG 5974-S, CG 5985-S, CG 6040-S* (https://archive.org/details/FBI-ELSUR-nsia/18-cv-01868%20pp%202770-3077%20-%20ELSUR%20Indices%20-%20Chicago%20Section%204/page/n299/mode/2up; https://archive.org/details/FBI-ELSUR-nsia/18-cv-01868%20pp%203298-2482%20-%20ELSUR%20Indices%20-%20Chicago%20Section%206/page/n93/mode/2up) Proof of death is not required as his death was widely reported: https://www.legacy.com/us/obituaries/chicagosuntimes/name/earl-durham-obituary?id=29644078 (This is a reprint of an obituary that originally appeared in the Chicago Sun-Times); https://www.ilga.gov/legislation/fulltext.asp?GAID=10&SessionID=76&GA=95&DocTypeID=SR&DocNum=422&LegID=48589&SpecSess=&Session= (Illinois State Senate resolution commemorating Durham)

Please conduct a search of the Central Records System, including but not limited to the Electronic Surveillance (ELSUR) Indices, the Microphone Surveillance (MISUR) Indices, the Physical Surveillance (FISUR) Indices, and the Technical Surveillance (TESUR) Indices, for both main-file records and cross-reference records for all relevant names, individuals, agencies and companies. This is also to include any responsive records held in offsite locations, such as the Alexandria Records Center. Please include both investigatory and non-investigatory records in your search. If any potentially responsive records have been destroyed and/or transferred to NARA, then I request copies of the destruction or transfer slips as well as any other documentation relating to, mentioning or describing said transfer or destruction, to include but not be limited to confirmation that the Bureau has no other copies of said records. If previously released records are available, then I request a rolling release consisting of those records while additional records are located and processed for release.

title: Seisint Incorporated

communications.subject: Freedom of Information Act Request: Seisint Incorporated
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Freedom of Information Act, I hereby request the following records:

DOJ/FBI records from (SEC trading review dated May 15, 2002), related to Seisint Inc. involvement with the investigation.

Page 2 notes DOJ involvement in the investigation:
https://unredacted.com/wp-content/uploads/2010/04/9-11-sec-report.pdf

Page 9 of MFR03010885 dated 9/16/03 states:

"At the conclusion of the investigation, the SEC gave DOJ a CD containing all the
relevant trades the SEC and the SROs had found. Cella then accompanied Paul Johns of
DOJ and FBI agent Gurvais Grigg to Seisint, a DOJ contractor based in Virgina, where
Seisint's computer experts "sliced and diced" the data on its powerful computers to
generate a series of reports. Johns, Grigg, and Cella reviewed these reports, which
revealed no evidence of illicit trading. Cella said the CD contained all of the trading
information obtained through the blue-sheeting process, which is a tremendous amount of
data."

https://cryptome.org/nara/sec/sec-03-0916.pdf

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 20 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Alan

Dear David Medeiros:
This letter is in response to your Freedom of Information Act (5 U.S.C. §552) request of
9/3/2024, which you sent to the Centers for Medicare & Medicaid Services (CMS). Within your
correspondence, you requested records relating to “Connecticut Medicaid Acquired Brain Injury
Waiver Program Records”.
After a careful search of the Centers for Medicare & Medicaid Services (CMS) files, i.e., a
search reasonably calculated to locate records responsive to your request and employing
reasonable standards, we were unable to locate any records responsive to your request. We were
informed that you may request the information directly from the state of Connecticut.
If you believe that the information withheld should not be exempt from disclosure, or this
response constitutes an adverse determination, you may appeal. By filing an appeal, you
preserve your rights under FOIA and give the agency a chance to review and reconsider your
request and the agency’s decision.
Your appeal must be mailed within 90 days from the date of receipt of this letter, to:
Principal Deputy Administrator
Centers for Medicare and Medicaid Services
Room C5-16-03
7500 Security Blvd.
Baltimore, Maryland 21244-1850
Please clearly mark both the envelope and your letter “Freedom of Information Act Appeal.”
If you would like to discuss our response before filing an appeal to attempt to resolve your
dispute without going through the appeals process, you may contact Angelica Holland or the
CMS FOIA Public Liaison for assistance at:
Desiree Gaynor

Dear Principal Deputy Administrators,

This appeal concerns CMS’s response to my Freedom of Information Act (FOIA) request, Control Number 090620247088, submitted on September 3, 2024, which sought records related to the “Connecticut Medicaid Acquired Brain Injury Waiver Program.” CMS’s determination that no responsive records exist violates statutory requirements under FOIA, the Americans with Disabilities Act (ADA), and principles enshrined in the United States Constitution, including the Fourteenth Amendment, the Supremacy Clause, and the First Amendment.

This letter outlines in detail why CMS’s response fails to meet legal, procedural, and ethical standards. It incorporates all required ADA accommodations and compliance demands, as well as a specific framework for remediation.

Executive Summary
This appeal identifies four critical deficiencies in CMS’s response:

Failure to Conduct a Reasonable Search: CMS did not perform a search reasonably calculated to locate all responsive documents, violating FOIA.
Non-Compliance with ADA Mandates: CMS failed to honor my ADA accommodations, violating federal law and constitutional protections under the Fourteenth Amendment.
Breach of Constitutional Accountability: CMS’s actions undermine rights protected under the Constitution, including due process, equal protection, and transparency obligations.
Violation of Public Accountability Principles: The absence of responsive records raises systemic concerns about transparency in federally funded programs.
I request immediate remediation, including a new search, explicit ADA compliance measures, and systemic reforms to ensure future accountability.

Detailed Grounds for Appeal
1. Failure to Conduct a Reasonable Search
FOIA requires that federal agencies conduct a search reasonably calculated to uncover all relevant records (5 U.S.C. § 552(a)(3)(C)). CMS’s claim that no responsive records exist is inconsistent with its statutory oversight role under the Medicaid program.

Statutory Obligations Require Record Existence:
CMS is required under 42 C.F.R. §§ 430.12 and 441.302 to maintain comprehensive documentation of Medicaid waivers, including:

Waiver applications submitted by the State of Connecticut.
CMS review and approval documentation.
Correspondence with the Connecticut Department of Social Services (DSS).
Reports on program outcomes, compliance, and funding.
Insufficient Search Methodology:
CMS failed to confirm whether relevant offices, databases, and third-party contractors were included in the search. Offices likely to have responsive records include:

Medicaid & CHIP Operations Group (MCOG)
Center for Medicaid & CHIP Services (CMCS)
Freedom of Information Group (FOIG)
Constitutional Implications:
The Fourteenth Amendment’s Equal Protection Clause guarantees fair and equal treatment under the law. CMS’s inadequate search undermines transparency and access to government-held information, a foundational principle of due process.

Requested Remedy:

Conduct a new search that includes all relevant offices, databases, and systems.
Provide documentation detailing the methodology, including:
Search terms used.
Personnel and divisions consulted.
Correspondence with contractors and state agencies.
Explain why records required under 42 C.F.R. §§ 430.12 and 441.302 are not available.
2. Non-Compliance with ADA Mandates
As an individual with a traumatic brain injury (TBI), I requested specific ADA accommodations in my FOIA request to ensure effective communication. CMS’s failure to provide these accommodations violates 42 U.S.C. § 12132 and 28 C.F.R. § 35.160.

ADA Accommodations Requested:

All correspondence embedded directly in the email body for accessibility.
Simplified summaries of complex records or correspondence.
Screen-reader compatible PDFs for any attachments.
These accommodations are non-negotiable and designed to reduce cognitive load and ensure equal access. CMS’s failure to comply with these requirements constitutes a direct violation of my rights under the ADA and the Rehabilitation Act of 1973 (29 U.S.C. § 794).

Precedent Supporting ADA Accommodations:
In Tennessee v. Lane, 541 U.S. 509 (2004), the U.S. Supreme Court reinforced that individuals with disabilities are entitled to accommodations that ensure their ability to participate fully in government processes.

Constitutional Implications:
By failing to provide effective communication, CMS violates the Fourteenth Amendment’s guarantee of equal protection and the Supremacy Clause, as federal ADA regulations preempt non-compliance.

Requested Remedy:

Confirm compliance with ADA accommodations in all future correspondence, including:
Use of the MuckRock platform as my sole communication method.
Embedding all text directly in email bodies for accessibility.
Provide a revised response to this appeal in full compliance with ADA standards.
Outline corrective measures CMS will implement to prevent future ADA violations.
3. Breach of Constitutional Accountability
Transparency and accountability are constitutional principles that underpin government operations. CMS’s inadequate response infringes on several key protections:

First Amendment: Public access to government-held information is an extension of free speech and a prerequisite for meaningful participation in democracy.
Fourteenth Amendment: CMS’s failure to provide a fair and equitable process for accessing records violates due process and equal protection rights.
Supremacy Clause (Article VI): Federal statutes, including FOIA and the ADA, preempt any agency practice that undermines compliance.
Requested Remedy:

Acknowledge constitutional obligations to provide transparency and accountability.
Confirm that all processes comply with constitutional and statutory protections.
4. Violation of Public Accountability Principles
The Connecticut Medicaid Acquired Brain Injury Waiver Program involves federal funds allocated to support individuals with disabilities. Records related to this program are essential for:

Ensuring compliance with program goals.
Safeguarding taxpayer dollars.
Protecting the rights of vulnerable populations.
Potential Implications of Missing Records:
CMS’s inability to locate responsive records raises systemic concerns about:

Record retention practices under the Federal Records Act (44 U.S.C. § 3101).
Oversight and compliance failures with Medicaid program goals.
Requested Remedy:

Confirm whether third-party contractors or state agencies were consulted during the search.
Provide responsive records or justify their absence.
Implement systemic reforms to improve transparency and accountability.
Escalation Pathways
If this appeal is not resolved satisfactorily, I will escalate the matter through the following channels:

U.S. Department of Justice, Civil Rights Division: For ADA non-compliance.
Office of Inspector General (HHS-OIG): For investigation into systemic failures.
Congressional Oversight Committees: To address broader accountability issues.
Judicial Review: Filing suit under 5 U.S.C. § 552(a)(4)(B) to compel compliance.
Conclusion
CMS’s response fails to meet its obligations under FOIA, the ADA, and the Constitution. I request:

A comprehensive search for responsive records, with detailed documentation of the process.
Immediate compliance with ADA accommodations, including exclusive use of the MuckRock platform for all correspondence.
A revised response to this appeal addressing the deficiencies outlined.
Please confirm receipt of this appeal and provide a full response no later than 20 business days from receipt, as required under FOIA. Failure to comply will result in immediate escalation.

Sincerely,
David Medeiros
ABI Resources, LLC


CC:
Desiree Gaynor, CMS FOIA Public Liaison
Office of Government Information Services (OGIS) 



1. Freedom of Information Act (FOIA) Compliance
Key Laws:
Freedom of Information Act (5 U.S.C. § 552)

Governs public access to federal agency records and requires "reasonable searches" for responsive documents.
Federal Records Act (44 U.S.C. § 3101)

Mandates proper creation, maintenance, and preservation of federal records.
Relevant Cases:
NARA v. Favish, 541 U.S. 157 (2004)

Agencies bear the burden of demonstrating the adequacy of their search and providing a justification for withholding records.
Church of Scientology v. IRS, 792 F.2d 146 (D.C. Cir. 1986)

Agencies must conduct a search "reasonably calculated to uncover all relevant documents."
Department of Justice v. Reporters Committee for Freedom of the Press, 489 U.S. 749 (1989)

Defines public interest in government transparency and accountability as fundamental to FOIA.
Wolf v. CIA, 473 F.3d 370 (D.C. Cir. 2007)

Courts review whether an agency’s FOIA search was conducted in good faith and was adequate in scope.
Kissinger v. Reporters Committee for Freedom of the Press, 445 U.S. 136 (1980)

Clarifies agency obligations under FOIA regarding the handling and preservation of federal records.
2. Americans with Disabilities Act (ADA) Compliance
Key Laws:
Americans with Disabilities Act (42 U.S.C. § 12132)

Prohibits discrimination against individuals with disabilities in accessing public services.
Section 504 of the Rehabilitation Act of 1973 (29 U.S.C. § 794)

Requires federally funded programs to provide reasonable accommodations for individuals with disabilities.
28 C.F.R. § 35.160

Establishes effective communication requirements for public entities under the ADA.
Relevant Cases:
Tennessee v. Lane, 541 U.S. 509 (2004)

Reinforces the right to reasonable accommodations to ensure equal access to public services.
Alexander v. Choate, 469 U.S. 287 (1985)

Prohibits policies or actions that disproportionately exclude individuals with disabilities from accessing public benefits.
Doe v. Regional School Unit 26, 928 F.3d 51 (1st Cir. 2019)

Public entities must provide reasonable accommodations to ensure effective communication.
Hale v. King, 642 F.3d 492 (5th Cir. 2011)

Federal agencies must comply with ADA requirements when responding to requests from individuals with disabilities.
3. Constitutional Protections
Key Provisions:
First Amendment

Protects the public’s right to access information as an extension of free speech.
Fourteenth Amendment

Guarantees due process and equal protection under the law, including rights to fair access to government processes.
Supremacy Clause (U.S. Const. art. VI)

Federal laws, such as FOIA and the ADA, preempt state or agency actions that violate these statutes.
Relevant Cases:
Lane v. Brown, 372 U.S. 477 (1963)

Ensures federal programs operate in a non-discriminatory manner consistent with constitutional protections.
Rosenberger v. Rector and Visitors of the University of Virginia, 515 U.S. 819 (1995)

Reinforces transparency as a principle integral to constitutional accountability.
Marbury v. Madison, 5 U.S. 137 (1803)

Establishes judicial review as a mechanism to ensure government compliance with constitutional and statutory requirements.
4. Government Accountability and Oversight
Key Laws:
Administrative Procedure Act (5 U.S.C. §§ 701–706)

Governs the process by which federal agencies operate and ensures accountability for agency actions.
Hatch Act (5 U.S.C. §§ 7321–7326)

Prohibits improper use of federal resources, ensuring ethical operations in federal agencies.
Inspector General Act of 1978 (5 U.S.C. App.)

Establishes mechanisms for independent oversight and investigation of agency misconduct.
Relevant Cases:
Chevron U.S.A., Inc. v. NRDC, 467 U.S. 837 (1984)

Agencies must justify actions under statutory frameworks, and judicial deference is contingent on compliance with the law.
Massachusetts v. EPA, 549 U.S. 497 (2007)

Agencies are obligated to provide reasoned explanations for decisions impacting public interest.
Salazar v. Buono, 559 U.S. 700 (2010)

Courts must ensure agencies operate in alignment with constitutional and statutory mandates.
5. Record Retention and Preservation
Key Laws:
Federal Records Act (44 U.S.C. §§ 3101–3107)

Requires agencies to create and maintain records documenting their activities.
Paperwork Reduction Act (44 U.S.C. §§ 3501–3521)

Ensures proper documentation and management of federal records to facilitate public access.
Relevant Cases:
Armstrong v. Executive Office of the President, 1 F.3d 1274 (D.C. Cir. 1993)

Agencies must ensure records are retained and accessible for public and legal purposes.
Public Citizen v. Carlin, 184 F.3d 900 (D.C. Cir. 1999)

Defines agency obligations for maintaining accessible and properly archived records.
6. FOIA and ADA Appeals
Key Precedents for Appeals:
Judicial Review of FOIA Denials:

Citizens for Responsibility and Ethics in Washington v. U.S. Department of Justice, 846 F.3d 1235 (D.C. Cir. 2017): Courts assess whether FOIA denials meet statutory standards.
ADA Appeals Mechanisms:

Guckenberg v. Boston College, 957 F. Supp. 306 (D. Mass. 1997): Courts reinforce that public entities must comply with ADA accommodation requests.

Inspector General Act of 1978 (5 U.S.C. App.)

Establishes mechanisms for independent oversight and investigation of agency misconduct.
Relevant Cases:
Chevron U.S.A., Inc. v. NRDC, 467 U.S. 837 (1984)

Agencies must justify actions under statutory frameworks, and judicial deference is contingent on compliance with the law.
Massachusetts v. EPA, 549 U.S. 497 (2007)

Agencies are obligated to provide reasoned explanations for decisions impacting public interest.
Salazar v. Buono, 559 U.S. 700 (2010)

Courts must ensure agencies operate in alignment with constitutional and statutory mandates.
5. Record Retention and Preservation
Key Laws:
Federal Records Act (44 U.S.C. §§ 3101–3107)

Requires agencies to create and maintain records documenting their activities.
Paperwork Reduction Act (44 U.S.C. §§ 3501–3521)

Ensures proper documentation and management of federal records to facilitate public access.
Relevant Cases:
Armstrong v. Executive Office of the President, 1 F.3d 1274 (D.C. Cir. 1993)

Agencies must ensure records are retained and accessible for public and legal purposes.
Public Citizen v. Carlin, 184 F.3d 900 (D.C. Cir. 1999)

Defines agency obligations for maintaining accessible and properly archived records.
6. FOIA and ADA Appeals
Key Precedents for Appeals:
Judicial Review of FOIA Denials:

Citizens for Responsibility and Ethics in Washington v. U.S. Department of Justice, 846 F.3d 1235 (D.C. Cir. 2017): Courts assess whether FOIA denials meet statutory standards.
ADA Appeals Mechanisms:

Guckenberg v. Boston College, 957 F. Supp. 306 (D. Mass. 1997): Courts reinforce that public entities must comply with ADA accommodation requests.

Dear Principal Deputy Administrators,

This appeal concerns CMS’s response to my Freedom of Information Act (FOIA) request, Control Number 090620247088, submitted on September 3, 2024, which sought records related to the “Connecticut Medicaid Acquired Brain Injury Waiver Program.” CMS’s determination that no responsive records exist violates statutory requirements under FOIA, the Americans with Disabilities Act (ADA), and principles enshrined in the United States Constitution, including the Fourteenth Amendment, the Supremacy Clause, and the First Amendment.

This letter outlines in detail why CMS’s response fails to meet legal, procedural, and ethical standards. It incorporates all required ADA accommodations and compliance demands, as well as a specific framework for remediation.

Executive Summary
This appeal identifies four critical deficiencies in CMS’s response:

Failure to Conduct a Reasonable Search: CMS did not perform a search reasonably calculated to locate all responsive documents, violating FOIA.
Non-Compliance with ADA Mandates: CMS failed to honor my ADA accommodations, violating federal law and constitutional protections under the Fourteenth Amendment.
Breach of Constitutional Accountability: CMS’s actions undermine rights protected under the Constitution, including due process, equal protection, and transparency obligations.
Violation of Public Accountability Principles: The absence of responsive records raises systemic concerns about transparency in federally funded programs.
I request immediate remediation, including a new search, explicit ADA compliance measures, and systemic reforms to ensure future accountability.

Detailed Grounds for Appeal
1. Failure to Conduct a Reasonable Search
FOIA requires that federal agencies conduct a search reasonably calculated to uncover all relevant records (5 U.S.C. § 552(a)(3)(C)). CMS’s claim that no responsive records exist is inconsistent with its statutory oversight role under the Medicaid program.

Statutory Obligations Require Record Existence:
CMS is required under 42 C.F.R. §§ 430.12 and 441.302 to maintain comprehensive documentation of Medicaid waivers, including:

Waiver applications submitted by the State of Connecticut.
CMS review and approval documentation.
Correspondence with the Connecticut Department of Social Services (DSS).
Reports on program outcomes, compliance, and funding.
Insufficient Search Methodology:
CMS failed to confirm whether relevant offices, databases, and third-party contractors were included in the search. Offices likely to have responsive records include:

Medicaid & CHIP Operations Group (MCOG)
Center for Medicaid & CHIP Services (CMCS)
Freedom of Information Group (FOIG)
Constitutional Implications:
The Fourteenth Amendment’s Equal Protection Clause guarantees fair and equal treatment under the law. CMS’s inadequate search undermines transparency and access to government-held information, a foundational principle of due process.

Requested Remedy:

Conduct a new search that includes all relevant offices, databases, and systems.
Provide documentation detailing the methodology, including:
Search terms used.
Personnel and divisions consulted.
Correspondence with contractors and state agencies.
Explain why records required under 42 C.F.R. §§ 430.12 and 441.302 are not available.
2. Non-Compliance with ADA Mandates
As an individual with a traumatic brain injury (TBI), I requested specific ADA accommodations in my FOIA request to ensure effective communication. CMS’s failure to provide these accommodations violates 42 U.S.C. § 12132 and 28 C.F.R. § 35.160.

ADA Accommodations Requested:

All correspondence embedded directly in the email body for accessibility.
Simplified summaries of complex records or correspondence.
Screen-reader compatible PDFs for any attachments.
These accommodations are non-negotiable and designed to reduce cognitive load and ensure equal access. CMS’s failure to comply with these requirements constitutes a direct violation of my rights under the ADA and the Rehabilitation Act of 1973 (29 U.S.C. § 794).

Precedent Supporting ADA Accommodations:
In Tennessee v. Lane, 541 U.S. 509 (2004), the U.S. Supreme Court reinforced that individuals with disabilities are entitled to accommodations that ensure their ability to participate fully in government processes.

Constitutional Implications:
By failing to provide effective communication, CMS violates the Fourteenth Amendment’s guarantee of equal protection and the Supremacy Clause, as federal ADA regulations preempt non-compliance.

Requested Remedy:

Confirm compliance with ADA accommodations in all future correspondence, including:
Use of the MuckRock platform as my sole communication method.
Embedding all text directly in email bodies for accessibility.
Provide a revised response to this appeal in full compliance with ADA standards.
Outline corrective measures CMS will implement to prevent future ADA violations.
3. Breach of Constitutional Accountability
Transparency and accountability are constitutional principles that underpin government operations. CMS’s inadequate response infringes on several key protections:

First Amendment: Public access to government-held information is an extension of free speech and a prerequisite for meaningful participation in democracy.
Fourteenth Amendment: CMS’s failure to provide a fair and equitable process for accessing records violates due process and equal protection rights.
Supremacy Clause (Article VI): Federal statutes, including FOIA and the ADA, preempt any agency practice that undermines compliance.
Requested Remedy:

Acknowledge constitutional obligations to provide transparency and accountability.
Confirm that all processes comply with constitutional and statutory protections.
4. Violation of Public Accountability Principles
The Connecticut Medicaid Acquired Brain Injury Waiver Program involves federal funds allocated to support individuals with disabilities. Records related to this program are essential for:

Ensuring compliance with program goals.
Safeguarding taxpayer dollars.
Protecting the rights of vulnerable populations.
Potential Implications of Missing Records:
CMS’s inability to locate responsive records raises systemic concerns about:

Record retention practices under the Federal Records Act (44 U.S.C. § 3101).
Oversight and compliance failures with Medicaid program goals.
Requested Remedy:

Confirm whether third-party contractors or state agencies were consulted during the search.
Provide responsive records or justify their absence.
Implement systemic reforms to improve transparency and accountability.
Escalation Pathways
If this appeal is not resolved satisfactorily, I will escalate the matter through the following channels:

U.S. Department of Justice, Civil Rights Division: For ADA non-compliance.
Office of Inspector General (HHS-OIG): For investigation into systemic failures.
Congressional Oversight Committees: To address broader accountability issues.
Judicial Review: Filing suit under 5 U.S.C. § 552(a)(4)(B) to compel compliance.
Conclusion
CMS’s response fails to meet its obligations under FOIA, the ADA, and the Constitution. I request:

A comprehensive search for responsive records, with detailed documentation of the process.
Immediate compliance with ADA accommodations, including exclusive use of the MuckRock platform for all correspondence.
A revised response to this appeal addressing the deficiencies outlined.
Please confirm receipt of this appeal and provide a full response no later than 20 business days from receipt, as required under FOIA. Failure to comply will result in immediate escalation.

Sincerely,
David Medeiros
ABI Resources, LLC


CC:
Desiree Gaynor, CMS FOIA Public Liaison
Office of Government Information Services (OGIS) 



1. Freedom of Information Act (FOIA) Compliance
Key Laws:
Freedom of Information Act (5 U.S.C. § 552)

Governs public access to federal agency records and requires "reasonable searches" for responsive documents.
Federal Records Act (44 U.S.C. § 3101)

Mandates proper creation, maintenance, and preservation of federal records.
Relevant Cases:
NARA v. Favish, 541 U.S. 157 (2004)

Agencies bear the burden of demonstrating the adequacy of their search and providing a justification for withholding records.
Church of Scientology v. IRS, 792 F.2d 146 (D.C. Cir. 1986)

Agencies must conduct a search "reasonably calculated to uncover all relevant documents."
Department of Justice v. Reporters Committee for Freedom of the Press, 489 U.S. 749 (1989)

Defines public interest in government transparency and accountability as fundamental to FOIA.
Wolf v. CIA, 473 F.3d 370 (D.C. Cir. 2007)

Courts review whether an agency’s FOIA search was conducted in good faith and was adequate in scope.
Kissinger v. Reporters Committee for Freedom of the Press, 445 U.S. 136 (1980)

Clarifies agency obligations under FOIA regarding the handling and preservation of federal records.
2. Americans with Disabilities Act (ADA) Compliance
Key Laws:
Americans with Disabilities Act (42 U.S.C. § 12132)

Prohibits discrimination against individuals with disabilities in accessing public services.
Section 504 of the Rehabilitation Act of 1973 (29 U.S.C. § 794)

Requires federally funded programs to provide reasonable accommodations for individuals with disabilities.
28 C.F.R. § 35.160

Establishes effective communication requirements for public entities under the ADA.
Relevant Cases:
Tennessee v. Lane, 541 U.S. 509 (2004)

Reinforces the right to reasonable accommodations to ensure equal access to public services.
Alexander v. Choate, 469 U.S. 287 (1985)

Prohibits policies or actions that disproportionately exclude individuals with disabilities from accessing public benefits.
Doe v. Regional School Unit 26, 928 F.3d 51 (1st Cir. 2019)

Public entities must provide reasonable accommodations to ensure effective communication.
Hale v. King, 642 F.3d 492 (5th Cir. 2011)

Federal agencies must comply with ADA requirements when responding to requests from individuals with disabilities.
3. Constitutional Protections
Key Provisions:
First Amendment

Protects the public’s right to access information as an extension of free speech.
Fourteenth Amendment

Guarantees due process and equal protection under the law, including rights to fair access to government processes.
Supremacy Clause (U.S. Const. art. VI)

Federal laws, such as FOIA and the ADA, preempt state or agency actions that violate these statutes.
Relevant Cases:
Lane v. Brown, 372 U.S. 477 (1963)

Ensures federal programs operate in a non-discriminatory manner consistent with constitutional protections.
Rosenberger v. Rector and Visitors of the University of Virginia, 515 U.S. 819 (1995)

Reinforces transparency as a principle integral to constitutional accountability.
Marbury v. Madison, 5 U.S. 137 (1803)

Establishes judicial review as a mechanism to ensure government compliance with constitutional and statutory requirements.
4. Government Accountability and Oversight
Key Laws:
Administrative Procedure Act (5 U.S.C. §§ 701–706)

Governs the process by which federal agencies operate and ensures accountability for agency actions.
Hatch Act (5 U.S.C. §§ 7321–7326)

Prohibits improper use of federal resources, ensuring ethical operations in federal agencies.
Inspector General Act of 1978 (5 U.S.C. App.)

Establishes mechanisms for independent oversight and investigation of agency misconduct.
Relevant Cases:
Chevron U.S.A., Inc. v. NRDC, 467 U.S. 837 (1984)

Agencies must justify actions under statutory frameworks, and judicial deference is contingent on compliance with the law.
Massachusetts v. EPA, 549 U.S. 497 (2007)

Agencies are obligated to provide reasoned explanations for decisions impacting public interest.
Salazar v. Buono, 559 U.S. 700 (2010)

Courts must ensure agencies operate in alignment with constitutional and statutory mandates.
5. Record Retention and Preservation
Key Laws:
Federal Records Act (44 U.S.C. §§ 3101–3107)

Requires agencies to create and maintain records documenting their activities.
Paperwork Reduction Act (44 U.S.C. §§ 3501–3521)

Ensures proper documentation and management of federal records to facilitate public access.
Relevant Cases:
Armstrong v. Executive Office of the President, 1 F.3d 1274 (D.C. Cir. 1993)

Agencies must ensure records are retained and accessible for public and legal purposes.
Public Citizen v. Carlin, 184 F.3d 900 (D.C. Cir. 1999)

Defines agency obligations for maintaining accessible and properly archived records.
6. FOIA and ADA Appeals
Key Precedents for Appeals:
Judicial Review of FOIA Denials:

Citizens for Responsibility and Ethics in Washington v. U.S. Department of Justice, 846 F.3d 1235 (D.C. Cir. 2017): Courts assess whether FOIA denials meet statutory standards.
ADA Appeals Mechanisms:

Guckenberg v. Boston College, 957 F. Supp. 306 (D. Mass. 1997): Courts reinforce that public entities must comply with ADA accommodation requests.

Failure to Conduct a Reasonable Search: CMS did not perform a search reasonably calculated to locate all responsive documents, violating FOIA.
Non-Compliance with ADA Mandates: CMS failed to honor my ADA accommodations, violating federal law and constitutional protections under the Fourteenth Amendment.
Breach of Constitutional Accountability: CMS’s actions undermine rights protected under the Constitution, including due process, equal protection, and transparency obligations.
Violation of Public Accountability Principles: The absence of responsive records raises systemic concerns about transparency in federally funded programs.
I request immediate remediation, including a new search, explicit ADA compliance measures, and systemic reforms to ensure future accountability.

Detailed Grounds for Appeal
1. Failure to Conduct a Reasonable Search
FOIA requires that federal agencies conduct a search reasonably calculated to uncover all relevant records (5 U.S.C. § 552(a)(3)(C)). CMS’s claim that no responsive records exist is inconsistent with its statutory oversight role under the Medicaid program.

Statutory Obligations Require Record Existence:
CMS is required under 42 C.F.R. §§ 430.12 and 441.302 to maintain comprehensive documentation of Medicaid waivers, including:

Waiver applications submitted by the State of Connecticut.
CMS review and approval documentation.
Correspondence with the Connecticut Department of Social Services (DSS).
Reports on program outcomes, compliance, and funding.
Insufficient Search Methodology:
CMS failed to confirm whether relevant offices, databases, and third-party contractors were included in the search. Offices likely to have responsive records include:

Medicaid & CHIP Operations Group (MCOG)
Center for Medicaid & CHIP Services (CMCS)
Freedom of Information Group (FOIG)
Constitutional Implications:
The Fourteenth Amendment’s Equal Protection Clause guarantees fair and equal treatment under the law. CMS’s inadequate search undermines transparency and access to government-held information, a foundational principle of due process.

Requested Remedy:

Conduct a new search that includes all relevant offices, databases, and systems.
Provide documentation detailing the methodology, including:
Search terms used.
Personnel and divisions consulted.
Correspondence with contractors and state agencies.
Explain why records required under 42 C.F.R. §§ 430.12 and 441.302 are not available.
2. Non-Compliance with ADA Mandates
As an individual with a traumatic brain injury (TBI), I requested specific ADA accommodations in my FOIA request to ensure effective communication. CMS’s failure to provide these accommodations violates 42 U.S.C. § 12132 and 28 C.F.R. § 35.160.

ADA Accommodations Requested:

All correspondence embedded directly in the email body for accessibility.
Simplified summaries of complex records or correspondence.
Screen-reader compatible PDFs for any attachments.
These accommodations are non-negotiable and designed to reduce cognitive load and ensure equal access. CMS’s failure to comply with these requirements constitutes a direct violation of my rights under the ADA and the Rehabilitation Act of 1973 (29 U.S.C. § 794).

Precedent Supporting ADA Accommodations:
In Tennessee v. Lane, 541 U.S. 509 (2004), the U.S. Supreme Court reinforced that individuals with disabilities are entitled to accommodations that ensure their ability to participate fully in government processes.

Constitutional Implications:
By failing to provide effective communication, CMS violates the Fourteenth Amendment’s guarantee of equal protection and the Supremacy Clause, as federal ADA regulations preempt non-compliance.

Requested Remedy:

Confirm compliance with ADA accommodations in all future correspondence, including:
Use of the MuckRock platform as my sole communication method.
Embedding all text directly in email bodies for accessibility.
Provide a revised response to this appeal in full compliance with ADA standards.
Outline corrective measures CMS will implement to prevent future ADA violations.
3. Breach of Constitutional Accountability
Transparency and accountability are constitutional principles that underpin government operations. CMS’s inadequate response infringes on several key protections:

First Amendment: Public access to government-held information is an extension of free speech and a prerequisite for meaningful participation in democracy.
Fourteenth Amendment: CMS’s failure to provide a fair and equitable process for accessing records violates due process and equal protection rights.
Supremacy Clause (Article VI): Federal statutes, including FOIA and the ADA, preempt any agency practice that undermines compliance.
Requested Remedy:

Acknowledge constitutional obligations to provide transparency and accountability.
Confirm that all processes comply with constitutional and statutory protections.
4. Violation of Public Accountability Principles
The Connecticut Medicaid Acquired Brain Injury Waiver Program involves federal funds allocated to support individuals with disabilities. Records related to this program are essential for:

Ensuring compliance with program goals.
Safeguarding taxpayer dollars.
Protecting the rights of vulnerable populations.
Potential Implications of Missing Records:
CMS’s inability to locate responsive records raises systemic concerns about:

Record retention practices under the Federal Records Act (44 U.S.C. § 3101).
Oversight and compliance failures with Medicaid program goals.
Requested Remedy:

Confirm whether third-party contractors or state agencies were consulted during the search.
Provide responsive records or justify their absence.
Implement systemic reforms to improve transparency and accountability.
Escalation Pathways
If this appeal is not resolved satisfactorily, I will escalate the matter through the following channels:

U.S. Department of Justice, Civil Rights Division: For ADA non-compliance.
Office of Inspector General (HHS-OIG): For investigation into systemic failures.
Congressional Oversight Committees: To address broader accountability issues.
Judicial Review: Filing suit under 5 U.S.C. § 552(a)(4)(B) to compel compliance.
Conclusion
CMS’s response fails to meet its obligations under FOIA, the ADA, and the Constitution. I request:

A comprehensive search for responsive records, with detailed documentation of the process.
Immediate compliance with ADA accommodations, including exclusive use of the MuckRock platform for all correspondence.
A revised response to this appeal addressing the deficiencies outlined.
Please confirm receipt of this appeal and provide a full response no later than 20 business days from receipt, as required under FOIA. Failure to comply will result in immediate escalation.

Sincerely,
David Medeiros
ABI Resources, LLC


CC:
Desiree Gaynor, CMS FOIA Public Liaison
Office of Government Information Services (OGIS) 



1. Freedom of Information Act (FOIA) Compliance
Key Laws:
Freedom of Information Act (5 U.S.C. § 552)

Governs public access to federal agency records and requires "reasonable searches" for responsive documents.
Federal Records Act (44 U.S.C. § 3101)

Mandates proper creation, maintenance, and preservation of federal records.
Relevant Cases:
NARA v. Favish, 541 U.S. 157 (2004)

Agencies bear the burden of demonstrating the adequacy of their search and providing a justification for withholding records.
Church of Scientology v. IRS, 792 F.2d 146 (D.C. Cir. 1986)

Agencies must conduct a search "reasonably calculated to uncover all relevant documents."
Department of Justice v. Reporters Committee for Freedom of the Press, 489 U.S. 749 (1989)

Defines public interest in government transparency and accountability as fundamental to FOIA.
Wolf v. CIA, 473 F.3d 370 (D.C. Cir. 2007)

Courts review whether an agency’s FOIA search was conducted in good faith and was adequate in scope.
Kissinger v. Reporters Committee for Freedom of the Press, 445 U.S. 136 (1980)

Clarifies agency obligations under FOIA regarding the handling and preservation of federal records.
2. Americans with Disabilities Act (ADA) Compliance
Key Laws:
Americans with Disabilities Act (42 U.S.C. § 12132)

Prohibits discrimination against individuals with disabilities in accessing public services.
Section 504 of the Rehabilitation Act of 1973 (29 U.S.C. § 794)

Requires federally funded programs to provide reasonable accommodations for individuals with disabilities.
28 C.F.R. § 35.160

Establishes effective communication requirements for public entities under the ADA.
Relevant Cases:
Tennessee v. Lane, 541 U.S. 509 (2004)

Reinforces the right to reasonable accommodations to ensure equal access to public services.
Alexander v. Choate, 469 U.S. 287 (1985)

Prohibits policies or actions that disproportionately exclude individuals with disabilities from accessing public benefits.
Doe v. Regional School Unit 26, 928 F.3d 51 (1st Cir. 2019)

Public entities must provide reasonable accommodations to ensure effective communication.
Hale v. King, 642 F.3d 492 (5th Cir. 2011)

Federal agencies must comply with ADA requirements when responding to requests from individuals with disabilities.
3. Constitutional Protections
Key Provisions:
First Amendment

Protects the public’s right to access information as an extension of free speech.
Fourteenth Amendment

Guarantees due process and equal protection under the law, including rights to fair access to government processes.
Supremacy Clause (U.S. Const. art. VI)

Federal laws, such as FOIA and the ADA, preempt state or agency actions that violate these statutes.
Relevant Cases:
Lane v. Brown, 372 U.S. 477 (1963)

Ensures federal programs operate in a non-discriminatory manner consistent with constitutional protections.
Rosenberger v. Rector and Visitors of the University of Virginia, 515 U.S. 819 (1995)

Reinforces transparency as a principle integral to constitutional accountability.
Marbury v. Madison, 5 U.S. 137 (1803)

Establishes judicial review as a mechanism to ensure government compliance with constitutional and statutory requirements.
4. Government Accountability and Oversight
Key Laws:
Administrative Procedure Act (5 U.S.C. §§ 701–706)

Governs the process by which federal agencies operate and ensures accountability for agency actions.
Hatch Act (5 U.S.C. §§ 7321–7326)

Prohibits improper use of federal resources, ensuring ethical operations in federal agencies.
Inspector General Act of 1978 (5 U.S.C. App.)

Establishes mechanisms for independent oversight and investigation of agency misconduct.
Relevant Cases:
Chevron U.S.A., Inc. v. NRDC, 467 U.S. 837 (1984)

Agencies must justify actions under statutory frameworks, and judicial deference is contingent on compliance with the law.
Massachusetts v. EPA, 549 U.S. 497 (2007)

Agencies are obligated to provide reasoned explanations for decisions impacting public interest.
Salazar v. Buono, 559 U.S. 700 (2010)

Courts must ensure agencies operate in alignment with constitutional and statutory mandates.
5. Record Retention and Preservation
Key Laws:
Federal Records Act (44 U.S.C. §§ 3101–3107)

Requires agencies to create and maintain records documenting their activities.
Paperwork Reduction Act (44 U.S.C. §§ 3501–3521)

Ensures proper documentation and management of federal records to facilitate public access.
Relevant Cases:
Armstrong v. Executive Office of the President, 1 F.3d 1274 (D.C. Cir. 1993)

Agencies must ensure records are retained and accessible for public and legal purposes.
Public Citizen v. Carlin, 184 F.3d 900 (D.C. Cir. 1999)

Defines agency obligations for maintaining accessible and properly archived records.
6. FOIA and ADA Appeals
Key Precedents for Appeals:
Judicial Review of FOIA Denials:

Citizens for Responsibility and Ethics in Washington v. U.S. Department of Justice, 846 F.3d 1235 (D.C. Cir. 2017): Courts assess whether FOIA denials meet statutory standards.
ADA Appeals Mechanisms:

Guckenberg v. Boston College, 957 F. Supp. 306 (D. Mass. 1997): Courts reinforce that public entities must comply with ADA accommodation requests.

Waiver applications submitted by the State of Connecticut.

Medicaid & CHIP Operations Group (MCOG)

Freedom of Information Group (FOIG)
Constitutional Implications:
The Fourteenth Amendment’s Equal Protection Clause guarantees fair and equal treatment under the law. CMS’s inadequate search undermines transparency and access to government-held information, a foundational principle of due process.

Requested Remedy:

Conduct a new search that includes all relevant offices, databases, and systems.
Provide documentation detailing the methodology, including:
Search terms used.
Personnel and divisions consulted.
Correspondence with contractors and state agencies.
Explain why records required under 42 C.F.R. §§ 430.12 and 441.302 are not available.
2. Non-Compliance with ADA Mandates
As an individual with a traumatic brain injury (TBI), I requested specific ADA accommodations in my FOIA request to ensure effective communication. CMS’s failure to provide these accommodations violates 42 U.S.C. § 12132 and 28 C.F.R. § 35.160.

All correspondence embedded directly in the email body for accessibility.

Use of the MuckRock platform as my sole communication method.

Provide a revised response to this appeal in full compliance with ADA standards.
Outline corrective measures CMS will implement to prevent future ADA violations.
3. Breach of Constitutional Accountability
Transparency and accountability are constitutional principles that underpin government operations. CMS’s inadequate response infringes on several key protections:

First Amendment: Public access to government-held information is an extension of free speech and a prerequisite for meaningful participation in democracy.
Fourteenth Amendment: CMS’s failure to provide a fair and equitable process for accessing records violates due process and equal protection rights.
Supremacy Clause (Article VI): Federal statutes, including FOIA and the ADA, preempt any agency practice that undermines compliance.

Protecting the rights of vulnerable populations.

Escalation Pathways
If this appeal is not resolved satisfactorily, I will escalate the matter through the following channels:

Office of Inspector General (HHS-OIG): For investigation into systemic failures.
Congressional Oversight Committees: To address broader accountability issues.
Judicial Review: Filing suit under 5 U.S.C. § 552(a)(4)(B) to compel compliance.
Conclusion
CMS’s response fails to meet its obligations under FOIA, the ADA, and the Constitution. I request:

Dear Principal Deputy Administrators,

This appeal concerns CMS’s response to my Freedom of Information Act (FOIA) request, Control Number 090620247088, submitted on September 3, 2024, which sought records related to the “Connecticut Medicaid Acquired Brain Injury Waiver Program.” CMS’s determination that no responsive records exist violates statutory requirements under FOIA, the Americans with Disabilities Act (ADA), and principles enshrined in the United States Constitution, including the Fourteenth Amendment, the Supremacy Clause, and the First Amendment.

This letter outlines in detail why CMS’s response fails to meet legal, procedural, and ethical standards. It incorporates all required ADA accommodations and compliance demands, as well as a specific framework for remediation.

Executive Summary
This appeal identifies four critical deficiencies in CMS’s response:

Failure to Conduct a Reasonable Search: CMS did not perform a search reasonably calculated to locate all responsive documents, violating FOIA.
Non-Compliance with ADA Mandates: CMS failed to honor my ADA accommodations, violating federal law and constitutional protections under the Fourteenth Amendment.
Breach of Constitutional Accountability: CMS’s actions undermine rights protected under the Constitution, including due process, equal protection, and transparency obligations.
Violation of Public Accountability Principles: The absence of responsive records raises systemic concerns about transparency in federally funded programs.
I request immediate remediation, including a new search, explicit ADA compliance measures, and systemic reforms to ensure future accountability.

Detailed Grounds for Appeal
1. Failure to Conduct a Reasonable Search
FOIA requires that federal agencies conduct a search reasonably calculated to uncover all relevant records (5 U.S.C. § 552(a)(3)(C)). CMS’s claim that no responsive records exist is inconsistent with its statutory oversight role under the Medicaid program.

Statutory Obligations Require Record Existence:
CMS is required under 42 C.F.R. §§ 430.12 and 441.302 to maintain comprehensive documentation of Medicaid waivers, including:

Waiver applications submitted by the State of Connecticut.
CMS review and approval documentation.
Correspondence with the Connecticut Department of Social Services (DSS).
Reports on program outcomes, compliance, and funding.
Insufficient Search Methodology:
CMS failed to confirm whether relevant offices, databases, and third-party contractors were included in the search. Offices likely to have responsive records include:

Medicaid & CHIP Operations Group (MCOG)
Center for Medicaid & CHIP Services (CMCS)
Freedom of Information Group (FOIG)
Constitutional Implications:
The Fourteenth Amendment’s Equal Protection Clause guarantees fair and equal treatment under the law. CMS’s inadequate search undermines transparency and access to government-held information, a foundational principle of due process.

Requested Remedy:

Conduct a new search that includes all relevant offices, databases, and systems.
Provide documentation detailing the methodology, including:
Search terms used.
Personnel and divisions consulted.
Correspondence with contractors and state agencies.
Explain why records required under 42 C.F.R. §§ 430.12 and 441.302 are not available.
2. Non-Compliance with ADA Mandates
As an individual with a traumatic brain injury (TBI), I requested specific ADA accommodations in my FOIA request to ensure effective communication. CMS’s failure to provide these accommodations violates 42 U.S.C. § 12132 and 28 C.F.R. § 35.160.

ADA Accommodations Requested:

All correspondence embedded directly in the email body for accessibility.
Simplified summaries of complex records or correspondence.
Screen-reader compatible PDFs for any attachments.
These accommodations are non-negotiable and designed to reduce cognitive load and ensure equal access. CMS’s failure to comply with these requirements constitutes a direct violation of my rights under the ADA and the Rehabilitation Act of 1973 (29 U.S.C. § 794).

Precedent Supporting ADA Accommodations:
In Tennessee v. Lane, 541 U.S. 509 (2004), the U.S. Supreme Court reinforced that individuals with disabilities are entitled to accommodations that ensure their ability to participate fully in government processes.

Constitutional Implications:
By failing to provide effective communication, CMS violates the Fourteenth Amendment’s guarantee of equal protection and the Supremacy Clause, as federal ADA regulations preempt non-compliance.

Requested Remedy:

Confirm compliance with ADA accommodations in all future correspondence, including:
Use of the MuckRock platform as my sole communication method.
Embedding all text directly in email bodies for accessibility.
Provide a revised response to this appeal in full compliance with ADA standards.
Outline corrective measures CMS will implement to prevent future ADA violations.
3. Breach of Constitutional Accountability
Transparency and accountability are constitutional principles that underpin government operations. CMS’s inadequate response infringes on several key protections:

First Amendment: Public access to government-held information is an extension of free speech and a prerequisite for meaningful participation in democracy.
Fourteenth Amendment: CMS’s failure to provide a fair and equitable process for accessing records violates due process and equal protection rights.
Supremacy Clause (Article VI): Federal statutes, including FOIA and the ADA, preempt any agency practice that undermines compliance.
Requested Remedy:

Acknowledge constitutional obligations to provide transparency and accountability.
Confirm that all processes comply with constitutional and statutory protections.
4. Violation of Public Accountability Principles
The Connecticut Medicaid Acquired Brain Injury Waiver Program involves federal funds allocated to support individuals with disabilities. Records related to this program are essential for:

Ensuring compliance with program goals.
Safeguarding taxpayer dollars.
Protecting the rights of vulnerable populations.
Potential Implications of Missing Records:
CMS’s inability to locate responsive records raises systemic concerns about:

Record retention practices under the Federal Records Act (44 U.S.C. § 3101).
Oversight and compliance failures with Medicaid program goals.
Requested Remedy:

Confirm whether third-party contractors or state agencies were consulted during the search.
Provide responsive records or justify their absence.
Implement systemic reforms to improve transparency and accountability.
Escalation Pathways
If this appeal is not resolved satisfactorily, I will escalate the matter through the following channels:

U.S. Department of Justice, Civil Rights Division: For ADA non-compliance.
Office of Inspector General (HHS-OIG): For investigation into systemic failures.
Congressional Oversight Committees: To address broader accountability issues.
Judicial Review: Filing suit under 5 U.S.C. § 552(a)(4)(B) to compel compliance.
Conclusion
CMS’s response fails to meet its obligations under FOIA, the ADA, and the Constitution. I request:

A comprehensive search for responsive records, with detailed documentation of the process.
Immediate compliance with ADA accommodations, including exclusive use of the MuckRock platform for all correspondence.
A revised response to this appeal addressing the deficiencies outlined.
Please confirm receipt of this appeal and provide a full response no later than 20 business days from receipt, as required under FOIA. Failure to comply will result in immediate escalation.

Sincerely,
David Medeiros
ABI Resources, LLC


CC:
Desiree Gaynor, CMS FOIA Public Liaison
Office of Government Information Services (OGIS) 



1. Freedom of Information Act (FOIA) Compliance
Key Laws:
Freedom of Information Act (5 U.S.C. § 552)

Governs public access to federal agency records and requires "reasonable searches" for responsive documents.
Federal Records Act (44 U.S.C. § 3101)

Mandates proper creation, maintenance, and preservation of federal records.
Relevant Cases:
NARA v. Favish, 541 U.S. 157 (2004)

Agencies bear the burden of demonstrating the adequacy of their search and providing a justification for withholding records.
Church of Scientology v. IRS, 792 F.2d 146 (D.C. Cir. 1986)

Agencies must conduct a search "reasonably calculated to uncover all relevant documents."
Department of Justice v. Reporters Committee for Freedom of the Press, 489 U.S. 749 (1989)

Defines public interest in government transparency and accountability as fundamental to FOIA.
Wolf v. CIA, 473 F.3d 370 (D.C. Cir. 2007)

Courts review whether an agency’s FOIA search was conducted in good faith and was adequate in scope.
Kissinger v. Reporters Committee for Freedom of the Press, 445 U.S. 136 (1980)

Clarifies agency obligations under FOIA regarding the handling and preservation of federal records.
2. Americans with Disabilities Act (ADA) Compliance
Key Laws:
Americans with Disabilities Act (42 U.S.C. § 12132)

Prohibits discrimination against individuals with disabilities in accessing public services.
Section 504 of the Rehabilitation Act of 1973 (29 U.S.C. § 794)

Requires federally funded programs to provide reasonable accommodations for individuals with disabilities.
28 C.F.R. § 35.160

Establishes effective communication requirements for public entities under the ADA.
Relevant Cases:
Tennessee v. Lane, 541 U.S. 509 (2004)

Reinforces the right to reasonable accommodations to ensure equal access to public services.
Alexander v. Choate, 469 U.S. 287 (1985)

Prohibits policies or actions that disproportionately exclude individuals with disabilities from accessing public benefits.
Doe v. Regional School Unit 26, 928 F.3d 51 (1st Cir. 2019)

Public entities must provide reasonable accommodations to ensure effective communication.
Hale v. King, 642 F.3d 492 (5th Cir. 2011)

Federal agencies must comply with ADA requirements when responding to requests from individuals with disabilities.
3. Constitutional Protections
Key Provisions:
First Amendment

Protects the public’s right to access information as an extension of free speech.
Fourteenth Amendment

Guarantees due process and equal protection under the law, including rights to fair access to government processes.
Supremacy Clause (U.S. Const. art. VI)

Federal laws, such as FOIA and the ADA, preempt state or agency actions that violate these statutes.
Relevant Cases:
Lane v. Brown, 372 U.S. 477 (1963)

Ensures federal programs operate in a non-discriminatory manner consistent with constitutional protections.
Rosenberger v. Rector and Visitors of the University of Virginia, 515 U.S. 819 (1995)

Reinforces transparency as a principle integral to constitutional accountability.
Marbury v. Madison, 5 U.S. 137 (1803)

Establishes judicial review as a mechanism to ensure government compliance with constitutional and statutory requirements.
4. Government Accountability and Oversight
Key Laws:
Administrative Procedure Act (5 U.S.C. §§ 701–706)

Governs the process by which federal agencies operate and ensures accountability for agency actions.
Hatch Act (5 U.S.C. §§ 7321–7326)

Prohibits improper use of federal resources, ensuring ethical operations in federal agencies.
Inspector General Act of 1978 (5 U.S.C. App.)

Establishes mechanisms for independent oversight and investigation of agency misconduct.
Relevant Cases:
Chevron U.S.A., Inc. v. NRDC, 467 U.S. 837 (1984)

Agencies must justify actions under statutory frameworks, and judicial deference is contingent on compliance with the law.
Massachusetts v. EPA, 549 U.S. 497 (2007)

Agencies are obligated to provide reasoned explanations for decisions impacting public interest.
Salazar v. Buono, 559 U.S. 700 (2010)

Courts must ensure agencies operate in alignment with constitutional and statutory mandates.
5. Record Retention and Preservation
Key Laws:
Federal Records Act (44 U.S.C. §§ 3101–3107)

Requires agencies to create and maintain records documenting their activities.
Paperwork Reduction Act (44 U.S.C. §§ 3501–3521)

Ensures proper documentation and management of federal records to facilitate public access.
Relevant Cases:
Armstrong v. Executive Office of the President, 1 F.3d 1274 (D.C. Cir. 1993)

Agencies must ensure records are retained and accessible for public and legal purposes.
Public Citizen v. Carlin, 184 F.3d 900 (D.C. Cir. 1999)

Defines agency obligations for maintaining accessible and properly archived records.
6. FOIA and ADA Appeals
Key Precedents for Appeals:
Judicial Review of FOIA Denials:

Citizens for Responsibility and Ethics in Washington v. U.S. Department of Justice, 846 F.3d 1235 (D.C. Cir. 2017): Courts assess whether FOIA denials meet statutory standards.
ADA Appeals Mechanisms:

Guckenberg v. Boston College, 957 F. Supp. 306 (D. Mass. 1997): Courts reinforce that public entities must comply with ADA accommodation requests.
