As an individual with a traumatic brain injury (TBI), I requested specific ADA accommodations in my FOIA request to ensure effective communication. CMS’s failure to provide these accommodations violates 42 U.S.C. § 12132 and 28 C.F.R. § 35.160.

ADA Accommodations Requested:

All correspondence embedded directly in the email body for accessibility.
Simplified summaries of complex records or correspondence.
Screen-reader compatible PDFs for any attachments.
These accommodations are non-negotiable and designed to reduce cognitive load and ensure equal access. CMS’s failure to comply with these requirements constitutes a direct violation of my rights under the ADA and the Rehabilitation Act of 1973 (29 U.S.C. § 794).

Precedent Supporting ADA Accommodations:
In Tennessee v. Lane, 541 U.S. 509 (2004), the U.S. Supreme Court reinforced that individuals with disabilities are entitled to accommodations that ensure their ability to participate fully in government processes.

Constitutional Implications:
By failing to provide effective communication, CMS violates the Fourteenth Amendment’s guarantee of equal protection and the Supremacy Clause, as federal ADA regulations preempt non-compliance.

Requested Remedy:

Confirm compliance with ADA accommodations in all future correspondence, including:
Use of the MuckRock platform as my sole communication method.
Embedding all text directly in email bodies for accessibility.
Provide a revised response to this appeal in full compliance with ADA standards.
Outline corrective measures CMS will implement to prevent future ADA violations.
3. Breach of Constitutional Accountability
Transparency and accountability are constitutional principles that underpin government operations. CMS’s inadequate response infringes on several key protections:

First Amendment: Public access to government-held information is an extension of free speech and a prerequisite for meaningful participation in democracy.
Fourteenth Amendment: CMS’s failure to provide a fair and equitable process for accessing records violates due process and equal protection rights.
Supremacy Clause (Article VI): Federal statutes, including FOIA and the ADA, preempt any agency practice that undermines compliance.
Requested Remedy:

Acknowledge constitutional obligations to provide transparency and accountability.
Confirm that all processes comply with constitutional and statutory protections.
4. Violation of Public Accountability Principles
The Connecticut Medicaid Acquired Brain Injury Waiver Program involves federal funds allocated to support individuals with disabilities. Records related to this program are essential for:

Ensuring compliance with program goals.
Safeguarding taxpayer dollars.
Protecting the rights of vulnerable populations.
Potential Implications of Missing Records:
CMS’s inability to locate responsive records raises systemic concerns about:

Record retention practices under the Federal Records Act (44 U.S.C. § 3101).
Oversight and compliance failures with Medicaid program goals.
Requested Remedy:

Confirm whether third-party contractors or state agencies were consulted during the search.
Provide responsive records or justify their absence.
Implement systemic reforms to improve transparency and accountability.
Escalation Pathways
If this appeal is not resolved satisfactorily, I will escalate the matter through the following channels:

U.S. Department of Justice, Civil Rights Division: For ADA non-compliance.
Office of Inspector General (HHS-OIG): For investigation into systemic failures.
Congressional Oversight Committees: To address broader accountability issues.
Judicial Review: Filing suit under 5 U.S.C. § 552(a)(4)(B) to compel compliance.
Conclusion
CMS’s response fails to meet its obligations under FOIA, the ADA, and the Constitution. I request:

A comprehensive search for responsive records, with detailed documentation of the process.
Immediate compliance with ADA accommodations, including exclusive use of the MuckRock platform for all correspondence.
A revised response to this appeal addressing the deficiencies outlined.
Please confirm receipt of this appeal and provide a full response no later than 20 business days from receipt, as required under FOIA. Failure to comply will result in immediate escalation.

Sincerely,
David Medeiros
ABI Resources, LLC

Office of Government Information Services (OGIS) 



1. Freedom of Information Act (FOIA) Compliance
Key Laws:
Freedom of Information Act (5 U.S.C. § 552)

Governs public access to federal agency records and requires "reasonable searches" for responsive documents.
Federal Records Act (44 U.S.C. § 3101)

Mandates proper creation, maintenance, and preservation of federal records.
Relevant Cases:
NARA v. Favish, 541 U.S. 157 (2004)

Agencies bear the burden of demonstrating the adequacy of their search and providing a justification for withholding records.
Church of Scientology v. IRS, 792 F.2d 146 (D.C. Cir. 1986)

Agencies must conduct a search "reasonably calculated to uncover all relevant documents."
Department of Justice v. Reporters Committee for Freedom of the Press, 489 U.S. 749 (1989)

Defines public interest in government transparency and accountability as fundamental to FOIA.
Wolf v. CIA, 473 F.3d 370 (D.C. Cir. 2007)

Courts review whether an agency’s FOIA search was conducted in good faith and was adequate in scope.
Kissinger v. Reporters Committee for Freedom of the Press, 445 U.S. 136 (1980)

Clarifies agency obligations under FOIA regarding the handling and preservation of federal records.
2. Americans with Disabilities Act (ADA) Compliance
Key Laws:
Americans with Disabilities Act (42 U.S.C. § 12132)

Prohibits discrimination against individuals with disabilities in accessing public services.
Section 504 of the Rehabilitation Act of 1973 (29 U.S.C. § 794)

Requires federally funded programs to provide reasonable accommodations for individuals with disabilities.
28 C.F.R. § 35.160

Establishes effective communication requirements for public entities under the ADA.
Relevant Cases:
Tennessee v. Lane, 541 U.S. 509 (2004)

Reinforces the right to reasonable accommodations to ensure equal access to public services.
Alexander v. Choate, 469 U.S. 287 (1985)

Prohibits policies or actions that disproportionately exclude individuals with disabilities from accessing public benefits.
Doe v. Regional School Unit 26, 928 F.3d 51 (1st Cir. 2019)

Public entities must provide reasonable accommodations to ensure effective communication.
Hale v. King, 642 F.3d 492 (5th Cir. 2011)

Federal agencies must comply with ADA requirements when responding to requests from individuals with disabilities.
3. Constitutional Protections
Key Provisions:
First Amendment

Protects the public’s right to access information as an extension of free speech.
Fourteenth Amendment

Guarantees due process and equal protection under the law, including rights to fair access to government processes.
Supremacy Clause (U.S. Const. art. VI)

Federal laws, such as FOIA and the ADA, preempt state or agency actions that violate these statutes.
Relevant Cases:
Lane v. Brown, 372 U.S. 477 (1963)

Ensures federal programs operate in a non-discriminatory manner consistent with constitutional protections.
Rosenberger v. Rector and Visitors of the University of Virginia, 515 U.S. 819 (1995)

Reinforces transparency as a principle integral to constitutional accountability.
Marbury v. Madison, 5 U.S. 137 (1803)

Establishes judicial review as a mechanism to ensure government compliance with constitutional and statutory requirements.
4. Government Accountability and Oversight
Key Laws:
Administrative Procedure Act (5 U.S.C. §§ 701–706)

Governs the process by which federal agencies operate and ensures accountability for agency actions.
Hatch Act (5 U.S.C. §§ 7321–7326)

Prohibits improper use of federal resources, ensuring ethical operations in federal agencies.
Inspector General Act of 1978 (5 U.S.C. App.)

Establishes mechanisms for independent oversight and investigation of agency misconduct.
Relevant Cases:
Chevron U.S.A., Inc. v. NRDC, 467 U.S. 837 (1984)

Agencies must justify actions under statutory frameworks, and judicial deference is contingent on compliance with the law.
Massachusetts v. EPA, 549 U.S. 497 (2007)

Agencies are obligated to provide reasoned explanations for decisions impacting public interest.
Salazar v. Buono, 559 U.S. 700 (2010)

Courts must ensure agencies operate in alignment with constitutional and statutory mandates.
5. Record Retention and Preservation
Key Laws:
Federal Records Act (44 U.S.C. §§ 3101–3107)

Requires agencies to create and maintain records documenting their activities.
Paperwork Reduction Act (44 U.S.C. §§ 3501–3521)

Ensures proper documentation and management of federal records to facilitate public access.
Relevant Cases:
Armstrong v. Executive Office of the President, 1 F.3d 1274 (D.C. Cir. 1993)

Agencies must ensure records are retained and accessible for public and legal purposes.
Public Citizen v. Carlin, 184 F.3d 900 (D.C. Cir. 1999)

Defines agency obligations for maintaining accessible and properly archived records.
6. FOIA and ADA Appeals
Key Precedents for Appeals:
Judicial Review of FOIA Denials:

Citizens for Responsibility and Ethics in Washington v. U.S. Department of Justice, 846 F.3d 1235 (D.C. Cir. 2017): Courts assess whether FOIA denials meet statutory standards.
ADA Appeals Mechanisms:

Guckenberg v. Boston College, 957 F. Supp. 306 (D. Mass. 1997): Courts reinforce that public entities must comply with ADA accommodation requests.

Dear Principal Deputy Administrators,

This appeal concerns CMS’s response to my Freedom of Information Act (FOIA) request, Control Number 090620247088, submitted on September 3, 2024, which sought records related to the “Connecticut Medicaid Acquired Brain Injury Waiver Program.” CMS’s determination that no responsive records exist violates statutory requirements under FOIA, the Americans with Disabilities Act (ADA), and principles enshrined in the United States Constitution, including the Fourteenth Amendment, the Supremacy Clause, and the First Amendment.

This letter outlines in detail why CMS’s response fails to meet legal, procedural, and ethical standards. It incorporates all required ADA accommodations and compliance demands, as well as a specific framework for remediation.

Executive Summary
This appeal identifies four critical deficiencies in CMS’s response:

Failure to Conduct a Reasonable Search: CMS did not perform a search reasonably calculated to locate all responsive documents, violating FOIA.
Non-Compliance with ADA Mandates: CMS failed to honor my ADA accommodations, violating federal law and constitutional protections under the Fourteenth Amendment.
Breach of Constitutional Accountability: CMS’s actions undermine rights protected under the Constitution, including due process, equal protection, and transparency obligations.
Violation of Public Accountability Principles: The absence of responsive records raises systemic concerns about transparency in federally funded programs.
I request immediate remediation, including a new search, explicit ADA compliance measures, and systemic reforms to ensure future accountability.

Detailed Grounds for Appeal
1. Failure to Conduct a Reasonable Search
FOIA requires that federal agencies conduct a search reasonably calculated to uncover all relevant records (5 U.S.C. § 552(a)(3)(C)). CMS’s claim that no responsive records exist is inconsistent with its statutory oversight role under the Medicaid program.

Statutory Obligations Require Record Existence:
CMS is required under 42 C.F.R. §§ 430.12 and 441.302 to maintain comprehensive documentation of Medicaid waivers, including:

Waiver applications submitted by the State of Connecticut.
CMS review and approval documentation.
Correspondence with the Connecticut Department of Social Services (DSS).
Reports on program outcomes, compliance, and funding.
Insufficient Search Methodology:
CMS failed to confirm whether relevant offices, databases, and third-party contractors were included in the search. Offices likely to have responsive records include:

Medicaid & CHIP Operations Group (MCOG)
Center for Medicaid & CHIP Services (CMCS)
Freedom of Information Group (FOIG)
Constitutional Implications:
The Fourteenth Amendment’s Equal Protection Clause guarantees fair and equal treatment under the law. CMS’s inadequate search undermines transparency and access to government-held information, a foundational principle of due process.

Requested Remedy:

Conduct a new search that includes all relevant offices, databases, and systems.
Provide documentation detailing the methodology, including:
Search terms used.
Personnel and divisions consulted.
Correspondence with contractors and state agencies.
Explain why records required under 42 C.F.R. §§ 430.12 and 441.302 are not available.
2. Non-Compliance with ADA Mandates
As an individual with a traumatic brain injury (TBI), I requested specific ADA accommodations in my FOIA request to ensure effective communication. CMS’s failure to provide these accommodations violates 42 U.S.C. § 12132 and 28 C.F.R. § 35.160.

ADA Accommodations Requested:

All correspondence embedded directly in the email body for accessibility.
Simplified summaries of complex records or correspondence.
Screen-reader compatible PDFs for any attachments.
These accommodations are non-negotiable and designed to reduce cognitive load and ensure equal access. CMS’s failure to comply with these requirements constitutes a direct violation of my rights under the ADA and the Rehabilitation Act of 1973 (29 U.S.C. § 794).

Precedent Supporting ADA Accommodations:
In Tennessee v. Lane, 541 U.S. 509 (2004), the U.S. Supreme Court reinforced that individuals with disabilities are entitled to accommodations that ensure their ability to participate fully in government processes.

Constitutional Implications:
By failing to provide effective communication, CMS violates the Fourteenth Amendment’s guarantee of equal protection and the Supremacy Clause, as federal ADA regulations preempt non-compliance.

Requested Remedy:

Confirm compliance with ADA accommodations in all future correspondence, including:
Use of the MuckRock platform as my sole communication method.
Embedding all text directly in email bodies for accessibility.
Provide a revised response to this appeal in full compliance with ADA standards.
Outline corrective measures CMS will implement to prevent future ADA violations.
3. Breach of Constitutional Accountability
Transparency and accountability are constitutional principles that underpin government operations. CMS’s inadequate response infringes on several key protections:

First Amendment: Public access to government-held information is an extension of free speech and a prerequisite for meaningful participation in democracy.
Fourteenth Amendment: CMS’s failure to provide a fair and equitable process for accessing records violates due process and equal protection rights.
Supremacy Clause (Article VI): Federal statutes, including FOIA and the ADA, preempt any agency practice that undermines compliance.
Requested Remedy:

Acknowledge constitutional obligations to provide transparency and accountability.
Confirm that all processes comply with constitutional and statutory protections.
4. Violation of Public Accountability Principles
The Connecticut Medicaid Acquired Brain Injury Waiver Program involves federal funds allocated to support individuals with disabilities. Records related to this program are essential for:

Ensuring compliance with program goals.
Safeguarding taxpayer dollars.
Protecting the rights of vulnerable populations.
Potential Implications of Missing Records:
CMS’s inability to locate responsive records raises systemic concerns about:

Record retention practices under the Federal Records Act (44 U.S.C. § 3101).
Oversight and compliance failures with Medicaid program goals.
Requested Remedy:

Confirm whether third-party contractors or state agencies were consulted during the search.
Provide responsive records or justify their absence.
Implement systemic reforms to improve transparency and accountability.
Escalation Pathways
If this appeal is not resolved satisfactorily, I will escalate the matter through the following channels:

U.S. Department of Justice, Civil Rights Division: For ADA non-compliance.
Office of Inspector General (HHS-OIG): For investigation into systemic failures.
Congressional Oversight Committees: To address broader accountability issues.
Judicial Review: Filing suit under 5 U.S.C. § 552(a)(4)(B) to compel compliance.
Conclusion
CMS’s response fails to meet its obligations under FOIA, the ADA, and the Constitution. I request:

A comprehensive search for responsive records, with detailed documentation of the process.
Immediate compliance with ADA accommodations, including exclusive use of the MuckRock platform for all correspondence.
A revised response to this appeal addressing the deficiencies outlined.
Please confirm receipt of this appeal and provide a full response no later than 20 business days from receipt, as required under FOIA. Failure to comply will result in immediate escalation.

Sincerely,
David Medeiros
ABI Resources, LLC

Dear Principal Deputy Administrators,

This appeal concerns CMS’s response to my Freedom of Information Act (FOIA) request, Control Number 090620247088, submitted on September 3, 2024, which sought records related to the “Connecticut Medicaid Acquired Brain Injury Waiver Program.” CMS’s determination that no responsive records exist violates statutory requirements under FOIA, the Americans with Disabilities Act (ADA), and principles enshrined in the United States Constitution, including the Fourteenth Amendment, the Supremacy Clause, and the First Amendment.

This letter outlines in detail why CMS’s response fails to meet legal, procedural, and ethical standards. It incorporates all required ADA accommodations and compliance demands, as well as a specific framework for remediation.

Executive Summary
This appeal identifies four critical deficiencies in CMS’s response:

Failure to Conduct a Reasonable Search: CMS did not perform a search reasonably calculated to locate all responsive documents, violating FOIA.
Non-Compliance with ADA Mandates: CMS failed to honor my ADA accommodations, violating federal law and constitutional protections under the Fourteenth Amendment.
Breach of Constitutional Accountability: CMS’s actions undermine rights protected under the Constitution, including due process, equal protection, and transparency obligations.
Violation of Public Accountability Principles: The absence of responsive records raises systemic concerns about transparency in federally funded programs.
I request immediate remediation, including a new search, explicit ADA compliance measures, and systemic reforms to ensure future accountability.

Detailed Grounds for Appeal
1. Failure to Conduct a Reasonable Search
FOIA requires that federal agencies conduct a search reasonably calculated to uncover all relevant records (5 U.S.C. § 552(a)(3)(C)). CMS’s claim that no responsive records exist is inconsistent with its statutory oversight role under the Medicaid program.

Statutory Obligations Require Record Existence:
CMS is required under 42 C.F.R. §§ 430.12 and 441.302 to maintain comprehensive documentation of Medicaid waivers, including:

Waiver applications submitted by the State of Connecticut.
CMS review and approval documentation.
Correspondence with the Connecticut Department of Social Services (DSS).
Reports on program outcomes, compliance, and funding.
Insufficient Search Methodology:
CMS failed to confirm whether relevant offices, databases, and third-party contractors were included in the search. Offices likely to have responsive records include:

Medicaid & CHIP Operations Group (MCOG)
Center for Medicaid & CHIP Services (CMCS)
Freedom of Information Group (FOIG)
Constitutional Implications:
The Fourteenth Amendment’s Equal Protection Clause guarantees fair and equal treatment under the law. CMS’s inadequate search undermines transparency and access to government-held information, a foundational principle of due process.

Requested Remedy:

Conduct a new search that includes all relevant offices, databases, and systems.
Provide documentation detailing the methodology, including:
Search terms used.
Personnel and divisions consulted.
Correspondence with contractors and state agencies.
Explain why records required under 42 C.F.R. §§ 430.12 and 441.302 are not available.
2. Non-Compliance with ADA Mandates
As an individual with a traumatic brain injury (TBI), I requested specific ADA accommodations in my FOIA request to ensure effective communication. CMS’s failure to provide these accommodations violates 42 U.S.C. § 12132 and 28 C.F.R. § 35.160.

ADA Accommodations Requested:

All correspondence embedded directly in the email body for accessibility.
Simplified summaries of complex records or correspondence.
Screen-reader compatible PDFs for any attachments.
These accommodations are non-negotiable and designed to reduce cognitive load and ensure equal access. CMS’s failure to comply with these requirements constitutes a direct violation of my rights under the ADA and the Rehabilitation Act of 1973 (29 U.S.C. § 794).

Precedent Supporting ADA Accommodations:
In Tennessee v. Lane, 541 U.S. 509 (2004), the U.S. Supreme Court reinforced that individuals with disabilities are entitled to accommodations that ensure their ability to participate fully in government processes.

Constitutional Implications:
By failing to provide effective communication, CMS violates the Fourteenth Amendment’s guarantee of equal protection and the Supremacy Clause, as federal ADA regulations preempt non-compliance.

Requested Remedy:

Confirm compliance with ADA accommodations in all future correspondence, including:
Use of the MuckRock platform as my sole communication method.
Embedding all text directly in email bodies for accessibility.
Provide a revised response to this appeal in full compliance with ADA standards.
Outline corrective measures CMS will implement to prevent future ADA violations.
3. Breach of Constitutional Accountability
Transparency and accountability are constitutional principles that underpin government operations. CMS’s inadequate response infringes on several key protections:

First Amendment: Public access to government-held information is an extension of free speech and a prerequisite for meaningful participation in democracy.
Fourteenth Amendment: CMS’s failure to provide a fair and equitable process for accessing records violates due process and equal protection rights.
Supremacy Clause (Article VI): Federal statutes, including FOIA and the ADA, preempt any agency practice that undermines compliance.
Requested Remedy:

Acknowledge constitutional obligations to provide transparency and accountability.
Confirm that all processes comply with constitutional and statutory protections.
4. Violation of Public Accountability Principles
The Connecticut Medicaid Acquired Brain Injury Waiver Program involves federal funds allocated to support individuals with disabilities. Records related to this program are essential for:

Ensuring compliance with program goals.
Safeguarding taxpayer dollars.
Protecting the rights of vulnerable populations.
Potential Implications of Missing Records:
CMS’s inability to locate responsive records raises systemic concerns about:

Record retention practices under the Federal Records Act (44 U.S.C. § 3101).
Oversight and compliance failures with Medicaid program goals.
Requested Remedy:

Confirm whether third-party contractors or state agencies were consulted during the search.
Provide responsive records or justify their absence.
Implement systemic reforms to improve transparency and accountability.
Escalation Pathways
If this appeal is not resolved satisfactorily, I will escalate the matter through the following channels:

U.S. Department of Justice, Civil Rights Division: For ADA non-compliance.
Office of Inspector General (HHS-OIG): For investigation into systemic failures.
Congressional Oversight Committees: To address broader accountability issues.
Judicial Review: Filing suit under 5 U.S.C. § 552(a)(4)(B) to compel compliance.
Conclusion
CMS’s response fails to meet its obligations under FOIA, the ADA, and the Constitution. I request:

A comprehensive search for responsive records, with detailed documentation of the process.
Immediate compliance with ADA accommodations, including exclusive use of the MuckRock platform for all correspondence.
A revised response to this appeal addressing the deficiencies outlined.
Please confirm receipt of this appeal and provide a full response no later than 20 business days from receipt, as required under FOIA. Failure to comply will result in immediate escalation.

Sincerely,
David Medeiros
ABI Resources, LLC


CC:
Desiree Gaynor, CMS FOIA Public Liaison
Office of Government Information Services (OGIS) 



1. Freedom of Information Act (FOIA) Compliance
Key Laws:
Freedom of Information Act (5 U.S.C. § 552)

Governs public access to federal agency records and requires "reasonable searches" for responsive documents.
Federal Records Act (44 U.S.C. § 3101)

Mandates proper creation, maintenance, and preservation of federal records.
Relevant Cases:
NARA v. Favish, 541 U.S. 157 (2004)

Agencies bear the burden of demonstrating the adequacy of their search and providing a justification for withholding records.
Church of Scientology v. IRS, 792 F.2d 146 (D.C. Cir. 1986)

Agencies must conduct a search "reasonably calculated to uncover all relevant documents."
Department of Justice v. Reporters Committee for Freedom of the Press, 489 U.S. 749 (1989)

Defines public interest in government transparency and accountability as fundamental to FOIA.
Wolf v. CIA, 473 F.3d 370 (D.C. Cir. 2007)

Courts review whether an agency’s FOIA search was conducted in good faith and was adequate in scope.
Kissinger v. Reporters Committee for Freedom of the Press, 445 U.S. 136 (1980)

Clarifies agency obligations under FOIA regarding the handling and preservation of federal records.
2. Americans with Disabilities Act (ADA) Compliance
Key Laws:
Americans with Disabilities Act (42 U.S.C. § 12132)

Prohibits discrimination against individuals with disabilities in accessing public services.
Section 504 of the Rehabilitation Act of 1973 (29 U.S.C. § 794)

Requires federally funded programs to provide reasonable accommodations for individuals with disabilities.
28 C.F.R. § 35.160

Establishes effective communication requirements for public entities under the ADA.
Relevant Cases:
Tennessee v. Lane, 541 U.S. 509 (2004)

Reinforces the right to reasonable accommodations to ensure equal access to public services.
Alexander v. Choate, 469 U.S. 287 (1985)

Prohibits policies or actions that disproportionately exclude individuals with disabilities from accessing public benefits.
Doe v. Regional School Unit 26, 928 F.3d 51 (1st Cir. 2019)

Public entities must provide reasonable accommodations to ensure effective communication.
Hale v. King, 642 F.3d 492 (5th Cir. 2011)

Federal agencies must comply with ADA requirements when responding to requests from individuals with disabilities.
3. Constitutional Protections
Key Provisions:
First Amendment

Protects the public’s right to access information as an extension of free speech.
Fourteenth Amendment

Guarantees due process and equal protection under the law, including rights to fair access to government processes.
Supremacy Clause (U.S. Const. art. VI)

Federal laws, such as FOIA and the ADA, preempt state or agency actions that violate these statutes.
Relevant Cases:
Lane v. Brown, 372 U.S. 477 (1963)

Ensures federal programs operate in a non-discriminatory manner consistent with constitutional protections.
Rosenberger v. Rector and Visitors of the University of Virginia, 515 U.S. 819 (1995)

Reinforces transparency as a principle integral to constitutional accountability.
Marbury v. Madison, 5 U.S. 137 (1803)

Establishes judicial review as a mechanism to ensure government compliance with constitutional and statutory requirements.
4. Government Accountability and Oversight
Key Laws:
Administrative Procedure Act (5 U.S.C. §§ 701–706)

Governs the process by which federal agencies operate and ensures accountability for agency actions.
Hatch Act (5 U.S.C. §§ 7321–7326)

Prohibits improper use of federal resources, ensuring ethical operations in federal agencies.
Inspector General Act of 1978 (5 U.S.C. App.)

Establishes mechanisms for independent oversight and investigation of agency misconduct.
Relevant Cases:
Chevron U.S.A., Inc. v. NRDC, 467 U.S. 837 (1984)

Agencies must justify actions under statutory frameworks, and judicial deference is contingent on compliance with the law.
Massachusetts v. EPA, 549 U.S. 497 (2007)

Agencies are obligated to provide reasoned explanations for decisions impacting public interest.
Salazar v. Buono, 559 U.S. 700 (2010)

Courts must ensure agencies operate in alignment with constitutional and statutory mandates.
5. Record Retention and Preservation
Key Laws:
Federal Records Act (44 U.S.C. §§ 3101–3107)

Requires agencies to create and maintain records documenting their activities.
Paperwork Reduction Act (44 U.S.C. §§ 3501–3521)

Ensures proper documentation and management of federal records to facilitate public access.
Relevant Cases:
Armstrong v. Executive Office of the President, 1 F.3d 1274 (D.C. Cir. 1993)

Agencies must ensure records are retained and accessible for public and legal purposes.
Public Citizen v. Carlin, 184 F.3d 900 (D.C. Cir. 1999)

Defines agency obligations for maintaining accessible and properly archived records.
6. FOIA and ADA Appeals
Key Precedents for Appeals:
Judicial Review of FOIA Denials:

Citizens for Responsibility and Ethics in Washington v. U.S. Department of Justice, 846 F.3d 1235 (D.C. Cir. 2017): Courts assess whether FOIA denials meet statutory standards.
ADA Appeals Mechanisms:

Guckenberg v. Boston College, 957 F. Supp. 306 (D. Mass. 1997): Courts reinforce that public entities must comply with ADA accommodation requests.

Ensuring compliance with program goals.
Safeguarding taxpayer dollars.
Protecting the rights of vulnerable populations.
Potential Implications of Missing Records:
CMS’s inability to locate responsive records raises systemic concerns about:

Record retention practices under the Federal Records Act (44 U.S.C. § 3101).
Oversight and compliance failures with Medicaid program goals.
Requested Remedy:

Confirm whether third-party contractors or state agencies were consulted during the search.
Provide responsive records or justify their absence.
Implement systemic reforms to improve transparency and accountability.
Escalation Pathways
If this appeal is not resolved satisfactorily, I will escalate the matter through the following channels:

U.S. Department of Justice, Civil Rights Division: For ADA non-compliance.
Office of Inspector General (HHS-OIG): For investigation into systemic failures.
Congressional Oversight Committees: To address broader accountability issues.
Judicial Review: Filing suit under 5 U.S.C. § 552(a)(4)(B) to compel compliance.
Conclusion
CMS’s response fails to meet its obligations under FOIA, the ADA, and the Constitution. I request:

A comprehensive search for responsive records, with detailed documentation of the process.
Immediate compliance with ADA accommodations, including exclusive use of the MuckRock platform for all correspondence.
A revised response to this appeal addressing the deficiencies outlined.
Please confirm receipt of this appeal and provide a full response no later than 20 business days from receipt, as required under FOIA. Failure to comply will result in immediate escalation.

Sincerely,
David Medeiros
ABI Resources, LLC


CC:
Desiree Gaynor, CMS FOIA Public Liaison
Office of Government Information Services (OGIS) 



1. Freedom of Information Act (FOIA) Compliance
Key Laws:
Freedom of Information Act (5 U.S.C. § 552)

Governs public access to federal agency records and requires "reasonable searches" for responsive documents.
Federal Records Act (44 U.S.C. § 3101)

Mandates proper creation, maintenance, and preservation of federal records.
Relevant Cases:
NARA v. Favish, 541 U.S. 157 (2004)

Agencies bear the burden of demonstrating the adequacy of their search and providing a justification for withholding records.
Church of Scientology v. IRS, 792 F.2d 146 (D.C. Cir. 1986)

Agencies must conduct a search "reasonably calculated to uncover all relevant documents."
Department of Justice v. Reporters Committee for Freedom of the Press, 489 U.S. 749 (1989)

Defines public interest in government transparency and accountability as fundamental to FOIA.
Wolf v. CIA, 473 F.3d 370 (D.C. Cir. 2007)

Courts review whether an agency’s FOIA search was conducted in good faith and was adequate in scope.
Kissinger v. Reporters Committee for Freedom of the Press, 445 U.S. 136 (1980)

Clarifies agency obligations under FOIA regarding the handling and preservation of federal records.
2. Americans with Disabilities Act (ADA) Compliance
Key Laws:
Americans with Disabilities Act (42 U.S.C. § 12132)

Prohibits discrimination against individuals with disabilities in accessing public services.
Section 504 of the Rehabilitation Act of 1973 (29 U.S.C. § 794)

Requires federally funded programs to provide reasonable accommodations for individuals with disabilities.
28 C.F.R. § 35.160

Establishes effective communication requirements for public entities under the ADA.
Relevant Cases:
Tennessee v. Lane, 541 U.S. 509 (2004)

Reinforces the right to reasonable accommodations to ensure equal access to public services.
Alexander v. Choate, 469 U.S. 287 (1985)

Prohibits policies or actions that disproportionately exclude individuals with disabilities from accessing public benefits.
Doe v. Regional School Unit 26, 928 F.3d 51 (1st Cir. 2019)

Public entities must provide reasonable accommodations to ensure effective communication.
Hale v. King, 642 F.3d 492 (5th Cir. 2011)

Federal agencies must comply with ADA requirements when responding to requests from individuals with disabilities.
3. Constitutional Protections
Key Provisions:
First Amendment

Protects the public’s right to access information as an extension of free speech.
Fourteenth Amendment

Guarantees due process and equal protection under the law, including rights to fair access to government processes.
Supremacy Clause (U.S. Const. art. VI)

Federal laws, such as FOIA and the ADA, preempt state or agency actions that violate these statutes.
Relevant Cases:
Lane v. Brown, 372 U.S. 477 (1963)

Ensures federal programs operate in a non-discriminatory manner consistent with constitutional protections.
Rosenberger v. Rector and Visitors of the University of Virginia, 515 U.S. 819 (1995)

Reinforces transparency as a principle integral to constitutional accountability.
Marbury v. Madison, 5 U.S. 137 (1803)

Establishes judicial review as a mechanism to ensure government compliance with constitutional and statutory requirements.
4. Government Accountability and Oversight
Key Laws:
Administrative Procedure Act (5 U.S.C. §§ 701–706)

Governs the process by which federal agencies operate and ensures accountability for agency actions.
Hatch Act (5 U.S.C. §§ 7321–7326)

Prohibits improper use of federal resources, ensuring ethical operations in federal agencies.
Inspector General Act of 1978 (5 U.S.C. App.)

Establishes mechanisms for independent oversight and investigation of agency misconduct.
Relevant Cases:
Chevron U.S.A., Inc. v. NRDC, 467 U.S. 837 (1984)

Agencies must justify actions under statutory frameworks, and judicial deference is contingent on compliance with the law.
Massachusetts v. EPA, 549 U.S. 497 (2007)

Agencies are obligated to provide reasoned explanations for decisions impacting public interest.
Salazar v. Buono, 559 U.S. 700 (2010)

Courts must ensure agencies operate in alignment with constitutional and statutory mandates.
5. Record Retention and Preservation
Key Laws:
Federal Records Act (44 U.S.C. §§ 3101–3107)

Requires agencies to create and maintain records documenting their activities.
Paperwork Reduction Act (44 U.S.C. §§ 3501–3521)

Ensures proper documentation and management of federal records to facilitate public access.
Relevant Cases:
Armstrong v. Executive Office of the President, 1 F.3d 1274 (D.C. Cir. 1993)

Agencies must ensure records are retained and accessible for public and legal purposes.
Public Citizen v. Carlin, 184 F.3d 900 (D.C. Cir. 1999)

Defines agency obligations for maintaining accessible and properly archived records.
6. FOIA and ADA Appeals
Key Precedents for Appeals:
Judicial Review of FOIA Denials:

Citizens for Responsibility and Ethics in Washington v. U.S. Department of Justice, 846 F.3d 1235 (D.C. Cir. 2017): Courts assess whether FOIA denials meet statutory standards.
ADA Appeals Mechanisms:

Guckenberg v. Boston College, 957 F. Supp. 306 (D. Mass. 1997): Courts reinforce that public entities must comply with ADA accommodation requests.

This letter is in response to your Freedom of Information Act (5 U.S.C. §552) request of

Dear Principal Deputy Administrators,

This appeal concerns CMS’s response to my Freedom of Information Act (FOIA) request, Control Number 090620247088, submitted on September 3, 2024, which sought records related to the “Connecticut Medicaid Acquired Brain Injury Waiver Program.” CMS’s determination that no responsive records exist violates statutory requirements under FOIA, the Americans with Disabilities Act (ADA), and principles enshrined in the United States Constitution, including the Fourteenth Amendment, the Supremacy Clause, and the First Amendment.

This letter outlines in detail why CMS’s response fails to meet legal, procedural, and ethical standards. It incorporates all required ADA accommodations and compliance demands, as well as a specific framework for remediation.

Executive Summary
This appeal identifies four critical deficiencies in CMS’s response:

Failure to Conduct a Reasonable Search: CMS did not perform a search reasonably calculated to locate all responsive documents, violating FOIA.
Non-Compliance with ADA Mandates: CMS failed to honor my ADA accommodations, violating federal law and constitutional protections under the Fourteenth Amendment.
Breach of Constitutional Accountability: CMS’s actions undermine rights protected under the Constitution, including due process, equal protection, and transparency obligations.
Violation of Public Accountability Principles: The absence of responsive records raises systemic concerns about transparency in federally funded programs.
I request immediate remediation, including a new search, explicit ADA compliance measures, and systemic reforms to ensure future accountability.

Detailed Grounds for Appeal
1. Failure to Conduct a Reasonable Search
FOIA requires that federal agencies conduct a search reasonably calculated to uncover all relevant records (5 U.S.C. § 552(a)(3)(C)). CMS’s claim that no responsive records exist is inconsistent with its statutory oversight role under the Medicaid program.

Statutory Obligations Require Record Existence:
CMS is required under 42 C.F.R. §§ 430.12 and 441.302 to maintain comprehensive documentation of Medicaid waivers, including:

Waiver applications submitted by the State of Connecticut.
CMS review and approval documentation.
Correspondence with the Connecticut Department of Social Services (DSS).
Reports on program outcomes, compliance, and funding.
Insufficient Search Methodology:
CMS failed to confirm whether relevant offices, databases, and third-party contractors were included in the search. Offices likely to have responsive records include:

Medicaid & CHIP Operations Group (MCOG)
Center for Medicaid & CHIP Services (CMCS)
Freedom of Information Group (FOIG)
Constitutional Implications:
The Fourteenth Amendment’s Equal Protection Clause guarantees fair and equal treatment under the law. CMS’s inadequate search undermines transparency and access to government-held information, a foundational principle of due process.

Requested Remedy:

Conduct a new search that includes all relevant offices, databases, and systems.
Provide documentation detailing the methodology, including:
Search terms used.
Personnel and divisions consulted.
Correspondence with contractors and state agencies.
Explain why records required under 42 C.F.R. §§ 430.12 and 441.302 are not available.
2. Non-Compliance with ADA Mandates
As an individual with a traumatic brain injury (TBI), I requested specific ADA accommodations in my FOIA request to ensure effective communication. CMS’s failure to provide these accommodations violates 42 U.S.C. § 12132 and 28 C.F.R. § 35.160.

ADA Accommodations Requested:

All correspondence embedded directly in the email body for accessibility.
Simplified summaries of complex records or correspondence.
Screen-reader compatible PDFs for any attachments.
These accommodations are non-negotiable and designed to reduce cognitive load and ensure equal access. CMS’s failure to comply with these requirements constitutes a direct violation of my rights under the ADA and the Rehabilitation Act of 1973 (29 U.S.C. § 794).

Precedent Supporting ADA Accommodations:
In Tennessee v. Lane, 541 U.S. 509 (2004), the U.S. Supreme Court reinforced that individuals with disabilities are entitled to accommodations that ensure their ability to participate fully in government processes.

Constitutional Implications:
By failing to provide effective communication, CMS violates the Fourteenth Amendment’s guarantee of equal protection and the Supremacy Clause, as federal ADA regulations preempt non-compliance.

Requested Remedy:

Confirm compliance with ADA accommodations in all future correspondence, including:
Use of the MuckRock platform as my sole communication method.
Embedding all text directly in email bodies for accessibility.
Provide a revised response to this appeal in full compliance with ADA standards.
Outline corrective measures CMS will implement to prevent future ADA violations.
3. Breach of Constitutional Accountability
Transparency and accountability are constitutional principles that underpin government operations. CMS’s inadequate response infringes on several key protections:

First Amendment: Public access to government-held information is an extension of free speech and a prerequisite for meaningful participation in democracy.
Fourteenth Amendment: CMS’s failure to provide a fair and equitable process for accessing records violates due process and equal protection rights.
Supremacy Clause (Article VI): Federal statutes, including FOIA and the ADA, preempt any agency practice that undermines compliance.
Requested Remedy:

Acknowledge constitutional obligations to provide transparency and accountability.
Confirm that all processes comply with constitutional and statutory protections.
4. Violation of Public Accountability Principles
The Connecticut Medicaid Acquired Brain Injury Waiver Program involves federal funds allocated to support individuals with disabilities. Records related to this program are essential for:

Ensuring compliance with program goals.
Safeguarding taxpayer dollars.
Protecting the rights of vulnerable populations.
Potential Implications of Missing Records:
CMS’s inability to locate responsive records raises systemic concerns about:

Record retention practices under the Federal Records Act (44 U.S.C. § 3101).
Oversight and compliance failures with Medicaid program goals.
Requested Remedy:

Confirm whether third-party contractors or state agencies were consulted during the search.
Provide responsive records or justify their absence.
Implement systemic reforms to improve transparency and accountability.
Escalation Pathways
If this appeal is not resolved satisfactorily, I will escalate the matter through the following channels:

U.S. Department of Justice, Civil Rights Division: For ADA non-compliance.
Office of Inspector General (HHS-OIG): For investigation into systemic failures.
Congressional Oversight Committees: To address broader accountability issues.
Judicial Review: Filing suit under 5 U.S.C. § 552(a)(4)(B) to compel compliance.
Conclusion
CMS’s response fails to meet its obligations under FOIA, the ADA, and the Constitution. I request:

A comprehensive search for responsive records, with detailed documentation of the process.
Immediate compliance with ADA accommodations, including exclusive use of the MuckRock platform for all correspondence.
A revised response to this appeal addressing the deficiencies outlined.
Please confirm receipt of this appeal and provide a full response no later than 20 business days from receipt, as required under FOIA. Failure to comply will result in immediate escalation.

Sincerely,
David Medeiros
ABI Resources, LLC

correspondence, you requested records relating to “Connecticut Medicaid Acquired Brain Injury
Waiver Program Records”.
After a careful search of the Centers for Medicare & Medicaid Services (CMS) files, i.e., a
search reasonably calculated to locate records responsive to your request and employing
reasonable standards, we were unable to locate any records responsive to your request. We were
informed that you may request the information directly from the state of Connecticut.
If you believe that the information withheld should not be exempt from disclosure, or this
response constitutes an adverse determination, you may appeal. By filing an appeal, you
preserve your rights under FOIA and give the agency a chance to review and reconsider your
request and the agency’s decision.
Your appeal must be mailed within 90 days from the date of receipt of this letter, to:

Dear Principal Deputy Administrators,

This appeal concerns CMS’s response to my Freedom of Information Act (FOIA) request, Control Number 090620247088, submitted on September 3, 2024, which sought records related to the “Connecticut Medicaid Acquired Brain Injury Waiver Program.” CMS’s determination that no responsive records exist violates statutory requirements under FOIA, the Americans with Disabilities Act (ADA), and principles enshrined in the United States Constitution, including the Fourteenth Amendment, the Supremacy Clause, and the First Amendment.

This letter outlines in detail why CMS’s response fails to meet legal, procedural, and ethical standards. It incorporates all required ADA accommodations and compliance demands, as well as a specific framework for remediation.

Executive Summary
This appeal identifies four critical deficiencies in CMS’s response:

Failure to Conduct a Reasonable Search: CMS did not perform a search reasonably calculated to locate all responsive documents, violating FOIA.
Non-Compliance with ADA Mandates: CMS failed to honor my ADA accommodations, violating federal law and constitutional protections under the Fourteenth Amendment.
Breach of Constitutional Accountability: CMS’s actions undermine rights protected under the Constitution, including due process, equal protection, and transparency obligations.
Violation of Public Accountability Principles: The absence of responsive records raises systemic concerns about transparency in federally funded programs.
I request immediate remediation, including a new search, explicit ADA compliance measures, and systemic reforms to ensure future accountability.

Detailed Grounds for Appeal
1. Failure to Conduct a Reasonable Search
FOIA requires that federal agencies conduct a search reasonably calculated to uncover all relevant records (5 U.S.C. § 552(a)(3)(C)). CMS’s claim that no responsive records exist is inconsistent with its statutory oversight role under the Medicaid program.

Statutory Obligations Require Record Existence:
CMS is required under 42 C.F.R. §§ 430.12 and 441.302 to maintain comprehensive documentation of Medicaid waivers, including:

Waiver applications submitted by the State of Connecticut.
CMS review and approval documentation.
Correspondence with the Connecticut Department of Social Services (DSS).
Reports on program outcomes, compliance, and funding.
Insufficient Search Methodology:
CMS failed to confirm whether relevant offices, databases, and third-party contractors were included in the search. Offices likely to have responsive records include:

Medicaid & CHIP Operations Group (MCOG)
Center for Medicaid & CHIP Services (CMCS)
Freedom of Information Group (FOIG)
Constitutional Implications:
The Fourteenth Amendment’s Equal Protection Clause guarantees fair and equal treatment under the law. CMS’s inadequate search undermines transparency and access to government-held information, a foundational principle of due process.

Requested Remedy:

Conduct a new search that includes all relevant offices, databases, and systems.
Provide documentation detailing the methodology, including:
Search terms used.
Personnel and divisions consulted.
Correspondence with contractors and state agencies.
Explain why records required under 42 C.F.R. §§ 430.12 and 441.302 are not available.
2. Non-Compliance with ADA Mandates
As an individual with a traumatic brain injury (TBI), I requested specific ADA accommodations in my FOIA request to ensure effective communication. CMS’s failure to provide these accommodations violates 42 U.S.C. § 12132 and 28 C.F.R. § 35.160.

ADA Accommodations Requested:

All correspondence embedded directly in the email body for accessibility.
Simplified summaries of complex records or correspondence.
Screen-reader compatible PDFs for any attachments.
These accommodations are non-negotiable and designed to reduce cognitive load and ensure equal access. CMS’s failure to comply with these requirements constitutes a direct violation of my rights under the ADA and the Rehabilitation Act of 1973 (29 U.S.C. § 794).

Precedent Supporting ADA Accommodations:
In Tennessee v. Lane, 541 U.S. 509 (2004), the U.S. Supreme Court reinforced that individuals with disabilities are entitled to accommodations that ensure their ability to participate fully in government processes.

Constitutional Implications:
By failing to provide effective communication, CMS violates the Fourteenth Amendment’s guarantee of equal protection and the Supremacy Clause, as federal ADA regulations preempt non-compliance.

Requested Remedy:

Confirm compliance with ADA accommodations in all future correspondence, including:
Use of the MuckRock platform as my sole communication method.
Embedding all text directly in email bodies for accessibility.
Provide a revised response to this appeal in full compliance with ADA standards.
Outline corrective measures CMS will implement to prevent future ADA violations.
3. Breach of Constitutional Accountability
Transparency and accountability are constitutional principles that underpin government operations. CMS’s inadequate response infringes on several key protections:

First Amendment: Public access to government-held information is an extension of free speech and a prerequisite for meaningful participation in democracy.
Fourteenth Amendment: CMS’s failure to provide a fair and equitable process for accessing records violates due process and equal protection rights.
Supremacy Clause (Article VI): Federal statutes, including FOIA and the ADA, preempt any agency practice that undermines compliance.
Requested Remedy:

Acknowledge constitutional obligations to provide transparency and accountability.
Confirm that all processes comply with constitutional and statutory protections.
4. Violation of Public Accountability Principles
The Connecticut Medicaid Acquired Brain Injury Waiver Program involves federal funds allocated to support individuals with disabilities. Records related to this program are essential for:

Ensuring compliance with program goals.
Safeguarding taxpayer dollars.
Protecting the rights of vulnerable populations.
Potential Implications of Missing Records:
CMS’s inability to locate responsive records raises systemic concerns about:

Record retention practices under the Federal Records Act (44 U.S.C. § 3101).
Oversight and compliance failures with Medicaid program goals.
Requested Remedy:

Confirm whether third-party contractors or state agencies were consulted during the search.
Provide responsive records or justify their absence.
Implement systemic reforms to improve transparency and accountability.
Escalation Pathways
If this appeal is not resolved satisfactorily, I will escalate the matter through the following channels:

U.S. Department of Justice, Civil Rights Division: For ADA non-compliance.
Office of Inspector General (HHS-OIG): For investigation into systemic failures.
Congressional Oversight Committees: To address broader accountability issues.
Judicial Review: Filing suit under 5 U.S.C. § 552(a)(4)(B) to compel compliance.
Conclusion
CMS’s response fails to meet its obligations under FOIA, the ADA, and the Constitution. I request:

A comprehensive search for responsive records, with detailed documentation of the process.
Immediate compliance with ADA accommodations, including exclusive use of the MuckRock platform for all correspondence.
A revised response to this appeal addressing the deficiencies outlined.
Please confirm receipt of this appeal and provide a full response no later than 20 business days from receipt, as required under FOIA. Failure to comply will result in immediate escalation.

Sincerely,
David Medeiros
ABI Resources, LLC


CC:
Desiree Gaynor, CMS FOIA Public Liaison
Office of Government Information Services (OGIS) 



1. Freedom of Information Act (FOIA) Compliance
Key Laws:
Freedom of Information Act (5 U.S.C. § 552)

Governs public access to federal agency records and requires "reasonable searches" for responsive documents.
Federal Records Act (44 U.S.C. § 3101)

Mandates proper creation, maintenance, and preservation of federal records.
Relevant Cases:
NARA v. Favish, 541 U.S. 157 (2004)

Agencies bear the burden of demonstrating the adequacy of their search and providing a justification for withholding records.
Church of Scientology v. IRS, 792 F.2d 146 (D.C. Cir. 1986)

Agencies must conduct a search "reasonably calculated to uncover all relevant documents."
Department of Justice v. Reporters Committee for Freedom of the Press, 489 U.S. 749 (1989)

Defines public interest in government transparency and accountability as fundamental to FOIA.
Wolf v. CIA, 473 F.3d 370 (D.C. Cir. 2007)

Courts review whether an agency’s FOIA search was conducted in good faith and was adequate in scope.
Kissinger v. Reporters Committee for Freedom of the Press, 445 U.S. 136 (1980)

Clarifies agency obligations under FOIA regarding the handling and preservation of federal records.
2. Americans with Disabilities Act (ADA) Compliance
Key Laws:
Americans with Disabilities Act (42 U.S.C. § 12132)

Prohibits discrimination against individuals with disabilities in accessing public services.
Section 504 of the Rehabilitation Act of 1973 (29 U.S.C. § 794)

Requires federally funded programs to provide reasonable accommodations for individuals with disabilities.
28 C.F.R. § 35.160

Establishes effective communication requirements for public entities under the ADA.
Relevant Cases:
Tennessee v. Lane, 541 U.S. 509 (2004)

Reinforces the right to reasonable accommodations to ensure equal access to public services.
Alexander v. Choate, 469 U.S. 287 (1985)

Prohibits policies or actions that disproportionately exclude individuals with disabilities from accessing public benefits.
Doe v. Regional School Unit 26, 928 F.3d 51 (1st Cir. 2019)

Public entities must provide reasonable accommodations to ensure effective communication.
Hale v. King, 642 F.3d 492 (5th Cir. 2011)

Federal agencies must comply with ADA requirements when responding to requests from individuals with disabilities.
3. Constitutional Protections
Key Provisions:
First Amendment

Protects the public’s right to access information as an extension of free speech.
Fourteenth Amendment

Guarantees due process and equal protection under the law, including rights to fair access to government processes.
Supremacy Clause (U.S. Const. art. VI)

Federal laws, such as FOIA and the ADA, preempt state or agency actions that violate these statutes.
Relevant Cases:
Lane v. Brown, 372 U.S. 477 (1963)

Ensures federal programs operate in a non-discriminatory manner consistent with constitutional protections.
Rosenberger v. Rector and Visitors of the University of Virginia, 515 U.S. 819 (1995)

Reinforces transparency as a principle integral to constitutional accountability.
Marbury v. Madison, 5 U.S. 137 (1803)

Establishes judicial review as a mechanism to ensure government compliance with constitutional and statutory requirements.
4. Government Accountability and Oversight
Key Laws:
Administrative Procedure Act (5 U.S.C. §§ 701–706)

Governs the process by which federal agencies operate and ensures accountability for agency actions.
Hatch Act (5 U.S.C. §§ 7321–7326)

Prohibits improper use of federal resources, ensuring ethical operations in federal agencies.
Inspector General Act of 1978 (5 U.S.C. App.)

Establishes mechanisms for independent oversight and investigation of agency misconduct.
Relevant Cases:
Chevron U.S.A., Inc. v. NRDC, 467 U.S. 837 (1984)

Agencies must justify actions under statutory frameworks, and judicial deference is contingent on compliance with the law.
Massachusetts v. EPA, 549 U.S. 497 (2007)

Agencies are obligated to provide reasoned explanations for decisions impacting public interest.
Salazar v. Buono, 559 U.S. 700 (2010)

Courts must ensure agencies operate in alignment with constitutional and statutory mandates.
5. Record Retention and Preservation
Key Laws:
Federal Records Act (44 U.S.C. §§ 3101–3107)

Requires agencies to create and maintain records documenting their activities.
Paperwork Reduction Act (44 U.S.C. §§ 3501–3521)

Ensures proper documentation and management of federal records to facilitate public access.
Relevant Cases:
Armstrong v. Executive Office of the President, 1 F.3d 1274 (D.C. Cir. 1993)

Agencies must ensure records are retained and accessible for public and legal purposes.
Public Citizen v. Carlin, 184 F.3d 900 (D.C. Cir. 1999)

Defines agency obligations for maintaining accessible and properly archived records.
6. FOIA and ADA Appeals
Key Precedents for Appeals:
Judicial Review of FOIA Denials:

Citizens for Responsibility and Ethics in Washington v. U.S. Department of Justice, 846 F.3d 1235 (D.C. Cir. 2017): Courts assess whether FOIA denials meet statutory standards.
ADA Appeals Mechanisms:

Guckenberg v. Boston College, 957 F. Supp. 306 (D. Mass. 1997): Courts reinforce that public entities must comply with ADA accommodation requests.

communications.subject: Colorado Open Records Act Request: Colorado Medicaid provider list
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Colorado Open Records Act, I hereby request the following records:

I am requesting an opportunity to inspect or obtain an updated electronic list of all Colorado Medicaid healthcare providers with the INCLUSION of their respective National Provider Identifier (NPI) numbers, medicaid ID and state license number (CSV or excel or TXT format are preferred). All types of healthcare practitioners from all dates electronically available (active, inactive and retired licensee data sets would be greatly appreciated. The specific items to be included in data set:

1. Provider first and last name
2. Medicaid Identification number 
3. National Provider Identifier (NPI) number
4. Colorado State License number and initial date of issuance or expiry (if available/applicable)
5. Education / School/Training, if available
6. Provider type (MD, DO, PA, RN, PT, OT, OD, CRNA, DMD, DDS, DPM etc)
7. Provider Specialty
8. Provider Practice Location (Including Practice Name)
9. Please include Data Dictionary describing state Medicaid Data Sets, if available.
10. Status of Active, Inactive, Retired

Thank you for considering my request.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 3 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Jenn Kellogg

title: Douglas PD Modified DESE Request

communications.subject: Massachusetts Public Records Law Request: Douglas PD Modified DESE Request
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Massachusetts Public Records Law, I hereby request the following records:

This letter constitutes a request pursuant to the Public Records Act, M. G. L.c.66, §10, for public records in the custody of your police department.

Under the Criminal Justice Reform Act, school districts and law enforcement agencies must “specify the manner and division of responsibility for collecting and reporting the school-based arrests, citations and court referrals of students to the Department of Elementary and Secondary Education” (DESE). DESE began collecting data on school-related arrests in the 2018-19 school year. In the 2019-20 school year, DESE has expanded that collection to include data on all referrals to law enforcement. DESE has defined these terms as follows, borrowing the same definitions used by the U.S. Department of Education since its 2009 Civil Rights Data Collection.

A school-related arrest “[r]efers to an arrest of a student for any activity conducted on school grounds, during off campus school activities (including while taking school transportation), or due to a referral by any school official. All school-related arrests are considered referrals to law enforcement.”

A referral to law enforcement “[i]s an action by which a student is reported to any law enforcement agency or official, including a school police unit, for an incident that occurs on school grounds, during school-related events, or while taking school transportation, regardless of whether official action is taken. Citations, tickets, court referrals, and school-related arrests are considered referrals to law enforcement.”

I request the following public records, as defined in M. G. L.c. 4, § 7 (twenty-sixth):

1. An extract of your records management system or database that includes each school-related arrest and each referral to law enforcement conducted during the 2018-2019, 2019-2020, 2020-2021, 2021-2022, and 2022-2023 school year (up until the day the records are produced). I request an extract of the database to be provided as an electronic spreadsheet (.xls, .xlsx, .csv, .tsv, or .ods format). If such format is unavailable, we request the extract of the database to be provided in a searchable, machine-readable form, as per 950 CMR 32.04(5).” Specifically, we request an extract of the database to include the following descriptions of the data in each column. This may be provided as clear, descriptive column headers in the database extract or in a separate document:

a. Date of arrest or referral to law enforcement

b. Time of arrest or referral to law enforcement

c. Charge (or charges)

d. Whether the individual(s) was arrested or referred to law enforcement

e. Sex of individual(s) arrested or referred to law enforcement

f. Age of individual(s) arrested or referred to law enforcement

g. Race of individual(s) arrested or referred to law enforcement

h. Ethnicity of individual(s) arrested or referred to law enforcement

i. Disability status of the individual(s) arrested or referred to law enforcement

j. Whether the individual arrested or referred to law enforcement is a student at the school.

k. Name of arresting officer, if applicable, and

l. Badge number of the arresting officer or the officer that referred the youth to law enforcement, as applicable.

m. Incident number or other unique identifier for each arrest or referral to law enforcement

n. Offender number or other unique identifier for each individual arrested or referred to law enforcement

2. If such an extract of the database in question 1 is not possible, please provide police reports and school incident reports on each school-related arrest conducted during the 2018-2019, 2019-2020, 2020-2021, 2021-2022, and 2022-2023 school year (up until the day the records are produced).

3. Please provide an unduplicated count of arrested students for each school year including 2018-2019, 2019-2020, 2020-2021, 2021-2022, and 2022-2023 school year (up until the day the records are produced).

4. If such an extract of the database in question 1 is not possible, please provide police reports and school incident reports on each referral to law enforcement conducted during the 2018-2019, 2019-2020, 2020-2021, 2021-2022, and 2022-2023 school year (up until

the day the records are produced), per the U.S. Department of Education’s Civil Rights Data Collection for that year. For each referral to law enforcement, please include the school, demographic, and incident information described in DESE’s School Safety and Discipline Report Data Handbook v. 20.0.

5. Please also provide an unduplicated counts of referrals to law enforcement (as defined above) for each school year including 2018-2019, 2019-2020, 2020-2021, 2021-2022 and 2022-2023 school year (up until the day the records are produced).

As this request involves a matter of public interest and will not be used for any commercial purpose, we ask that all fees associated with this request be waived pursuant to 950 C.M.R. 32.07(2)(k). The purpose of this request is to determine whether your school district and police department are complying with their reporting obligations under the Criminal Justice Reform Act. “The public has an interest in knowing whether public servants are carrying out their duties in an efficient and law-abiding manner.”

It would be ill-advised to impose a fee for data that your police department may have failed to report in violation of statutory and regulatory duty. Moreover, as you know, municipalities with a population of over 20,000 may not assess a fee for the first 2 hours of time spent searching for, compiling, segregating, redacting and reproducing a requested record. Finally, pursuant to 950 C.M.R. 32.07(2)(i), a records access officer shall assess no fee greater than the lowest hourly rate of a person capable of compiling, segregating, redacting and reproducing a requested record. In the event that a charge is incurred for this request which you will not waive, please so indicate and include an itemization of estimated good faith costs.

Please provide public records to a requestor in an electronic format unless the record is not available in an electronic format. M. G. L.c 66, § 6A(d).

The Public Records Act requires that you comply with this request within ten (10) business days following receipt. If you believe that documents or data responsive to any request herein is not public record and thus not subject to disclosure, please set forth in writing the specific reasons for such assertion, including the specific exemption or exemptions that you believe apply. To the extent that you determine that records need to be redacted in order to be produced under any law protecting the privacy of named individuals, please do so rather than withholding them in their entirety.

If you have any questions about this request, or need additional time to respond, please contact me. Thank you in advance for your prompt response to this request.

Sincerely,

Katherine Stathulis

J.D. Research Fellow

Center for Public Interest, Advocacy, and Collaboration k.stathulis@northeastern.edu

617-373-5862

I also request that, if appropriate, fees be waived as we believe this request is in the public interest, as suggested but not stipulated by the recommendations of the Massachusetts Supervisor of Public Records. The requested documents will be made available to the general public free of charge as part of the public information service at MuckRock.com, and is not made for commercial usage.

I expect the request to be filled in an accessible format, including for screen readers, which provide text-to-speech for persons unable to read print. Files that are not accessible to screen readers include, for example, .pdf image files as well as physical documents.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 10 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Rylee Meints

title: FBI: Seattle boxer Kenno Carlos

communications.subject: Freedom of Information Act Request: FBI: Seattle boxer Kenno Carlos
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Freedom of Information Act, I hereby request the following records:

Records mentioning, relating to, or generated as a result of investigation or inquiry or FBI association with a prominent Seattle-area boxer and associate of the Seattle chapter of the Black Panther Party named Kenno Carlos. Kenno Carlos is deceased and thus privacy concerns under FOIA Exemptions 6 and 7 are voided, as are any concerns under the Privacy Act. Mr. Kenno Carlos was born on November 28th of 1938 in Capitol Heights in Maryland, and died on December 29th of 2008. A photograph of his headstone and burial plot in the Forest Lawn cemetery in Seattle is available online: https://www.findagrave.com/memorial/159350303/kenno-carlos

On May 23rd of 1968 Kenno Carlos was arrested in a flag burning episode in Seattle that made local news: https://www.historylink.org/File/1456

According to evidence presented by the House Committee on Internal Security in 1970, Mr. Kenno Carlos of Seattle was included in a publicly released list of individuals, "identified as Seattle Panther Party members or associates who, at various times between April 1968 and March 1970, participated in Panther functions regularly." A link to that document from the House Committee on Internal Security can be found here: https://blackfreedom.proquest.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/09/blackpanther20.pdf

Other known aliases for Kenno Carlos, according to the congressional report, include the names Joseph Edward Hall and Charlie Reno. In December of 1972 news articles describe Kenno Carlos boxing under the name "Big" Charlie Reno: https://www.boxingforum24.com/threads/ken-norton-vs-big-charlie-reno-december-13-1972.433709/ 

This request is for any and all records about the boxer Kenno Carlos from any and all FBI offices, including HQ, field offices, legal attaches, and facilities that maintain records under the FBI’s control. Please conduct a search for any records on Kenno Carlos held by the Seattle office. According to a blog post I just read, it is important that I state the following: "As you know, your agency is required to search the records stored at NARA’s Washington Records Center in Suitland, MD, but still technically under your agency’s control. For more information see 36 CFR 1250.8" Please also conduct a physical search of records at NARA's Washington Records Center in Suitland, for any records or documents related to Kenno Carlos.

Please include all potentially responsive materials, including but not limited to all communications, reports, inquiries, investigations, photographs, audio files, video files, memos, directives, etc. Please include all materials found in other subject files and all materials associated with any potentially-related names and any other known aliases (including "Joseph Edward Hall" and "Charlie Reno"), nicknames ("Big Charlie"), code names, or any other identifying pseudonyms or references utilized by this agency. Please consult the Central Records System and records, the Electronic Surveillance (ELSUR) Data Management System and records, Microphone Surveillance (MISUR) records, Physical Surveillance (FISUR) records, Technical Surveillance (TESUR) records, and all available cross-reference indices, databases, and records, in addition to any other locations containing potentially-responsive materials related to Kenno Carlos.

Please include a search of any records or documents understood to be, or colloquially referred to as "COINTELPRO records" under the bureau's custody that could be construed as responsive to a request for records related to Kenno Carlos. Possible bureau documentation on Kenno Carlos would likely include the flag burning episode and associated media coverage, Black Panther material and documents, etc. 

If the bureau cannot fulfill certain parts of this request or if certain portions must be redacted, please provide any reasonable segregable portion of a requested record after removing or redacting those portions claimed to be exempt, explain in writing the justification for redacting the record, indicate the extent of any redactions on the portion of the record which is made available or published and where technically feasible indicate on the redacted portion itself the specific exemption(s) claimed.

Thank you for the bureau's commitment to transparency, and I look forward to working together in having this request resolved. Thank you.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 20 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Robert Delaware

title: Agency Roster (West Sacramento Police Department)

communications.subject: California Public Records Act Request: Agency Roster (West Sacramento Police Department)
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the California Public Records Act, I hereby request the following records:

Please provide records sufficient to show a current staff roster of all sworn employees with your agency.

Please include;
- first and last name of each employee with their corresponding;
- badge number
- employee identification number
- hire date
- rank or position
- assigned duty station/substation/precinct/location
- current salary

This request applies to ALL sworn Department employees, including those at substations.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 10 calendar days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Marcus Boyd

communications.subject: Your West Sacramento public records request #24-455 has been submitted.
communications.communication:
West Sacramento ************************************************************************ Your record request #24-455 has been submitted successfully. Your records request has been received and forwarded to the appropriate staff member for review.  You will be notified within (10) days whether your request seeks copies of disclosable public records in the possession of this agency. In most cases, your request will be processed in two to four weeks, or sooner.  The City may invoke an extension of time to determine if there is a need to: * Search for and collect the requested records from field facilities. * Search for and examine a voluminous number of records. * Consult with another agency or City departments having a substantial interest in the determination of the request. * Compile data. If your request is to review records (rather than receive copies), an appointment will be made with you for review once the records are gathered.  Please note:  If any responsive documents are copyrighted they can only be viewed in house.  No duplicate or photos are allowed. There is a charge for the direct cost of duplication pursuant to the City’s Book of fees. Payment must be made prior to release of records requested. If the documents requested exceed 50 pages, a deposit may be requested. Records available for review and/or copies of records requested will be available for 10 days after notification of their availability. If you are unable to pick-up or view your records during this time period, notification is required or your request will be considered fulfilled and a new request must be made. Certain records are generally exempt for disclosure pursuant to Government Code Section 6255, where the public interest served by not making the records public clearly outweighs the public interest served by disclosure of the records. The Government Code further provides that certain other records are specifically exempt from disclosure. JANET CHAPAN, MMC Sr. Deputy City Clerk 1110 W.
